In order to successfully combat the corona pandemic and protect the Austrian health system, a high vaccination rate is necessary. Therefore, a general COVID-19 vaccination has been mandatory in Austria since February 5th. In the run-up, there was broad coordination at political and social level in order to be able to take into account as many aspects and effects on our social coexistence as possible.    Source: https://archive.vn/PrqfI#selection-1171.0-1179.181 [COVID-19 vaccination compulsory from February 2022]

Retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled    Entering old people's and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled is only permitted under certain conditions:  â¢	Maximum number of visitors: a maximum of two visits are permitted per resident per day,  o	In addition, a maximum of two people to accompany underage residents of residential facilities for the disabled per day,  o	in addition, a maximum of two people per resident in need of support per day if they perform regular support and care tasks. In the event of a positive test result, admission can still take place if there are at least 48 hours of symptoms after the infection has expired and it can be assumed on the basis of the medical laboratory findings, in particular based on a CT value >30, that there is no longer any risk of infection.  o	Exceptions: Visits within the framework of palliative care and hospice care, pastoral care and support for critical life events, external service providers, legally defined representatives, bodies responsible for care supervision or members of established commissions.   â¢	When entering old people's and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled, residents in generally accessible places that are not part of the residential area, as well as visitors and accompanying persons, must wear a mask.  â¢	If it can be credibly demonstrated that a negative PCR test cannot be presented for reasons of lack of availability, an untimely evaluation or due to the unpredictability of the official activity to be performed, operators may exceptionally admit persons even if they have 3G proof submit. This also applies to operators.  â¢	The planned measures must not be disproportionate or lead to unreasonable hardship.    The following generally applies to visitors:  â¢	The operator may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show proof of 2G and also have a negative PCR test that was taken no more than 72 hours ago. In the event of a positive test result, admission can still take place if there are at least 48 hours of symptoms after the infection has expired and it can be assumed on the basis of the medical laboratory findings, in particular based on a CT value >30, that there is no longer any risk of infection.  â¢	Exceptions: Accompanying persons of underage residents in inpatient residential facilities for the disabled and for visitors of palliative and hospice patients.  â¢	The operator may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they wear an FFP2 mask throughout the visit or stay.    The following applies to employees:   â¢	The operator may only let employees in if they can show proof of 2G. If one cannot be presented, a valid PCR test must be presented. In the event of a positive test result, admission can still be granted if there are at least 48 hours of symptoms after the infection has expired and it can be assumed on the basis of the medical laboratory findings, in particular based on a CT value >30, that there is no longer any risk of infection.  â¢	Employees must wear an FFP2 mask in closed rooms.    The following applies to operators:  â¢	The operator of old people's and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled may only admit residents to new admissions if they can show proof of 2.5G.  â¢	The operator of retirement and nursing homes must offer residents an antigen test for SARS-CoV-2 or a molecular biological test for SARS-CoV-2 at least every seven days, but if they have left the home within this period.  â¢	The operator must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220124203718/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220124204625/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/

Retirement and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled    Entering old people's and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled is only permitted under certain conditions:  â¢	Maximum number of visitors: a maximum of two visits are permitted per resident per day,  	o	In addition, a maximum of two people to accompany underage residents of residential facilities for the disabled per day,  	o	in addition, a maximum of two people per resident in need of support per day if they perform regular support and care tasks. In the event of a positive test result, admission can still take place if there are at least 48 hours of symptoms after the infection has expired and it can be assumed on the basis of the medical laboratory findings, in particular based on a CT value >30, that there is no longer any risk of infection.  	o	Exceptions: Visits within the framework of palliative care and hospice care, pastoral care and support for critical life events, external service providers, legally defined representatives, bodies responsible for care supervision or members of established commissions.   â¢	When entering old people's and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled, residents in generally accessible places that are not part of the residential area, as well as visitors and accompanying persons, must wear a mask.  â¢	If it can be credibly demonstrated that a negative PCR test cannot be presented for reasons of lack of availability, an untimely evaluation or due to the unpredictability of the official activity to be performed, operators may exceptionally admit persons even if they have 3G proof submit. This also applies to operators.  â¢	The planned measures must not be disproportionate or lead to unreasonable hardship.    The following generally applies to visitors:  â¢	The operator may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show proof of 2G and also have a negative PCR test that was taken no more than 72 hours ago. In the event of a positive test result, admission can still be granted if there are at least 48 hours of symptoms after the infection has expired and it can be assumed on the basis of the medical laboratory findings, in particular based on a CT value >30, that there is no longer any risk of infection.  â¢	Exceptions: Accompanying persons of underage residents in inpatient residential facilities for the disabled and for visitors of palliative and hospice patients.  â¢	The operator may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they wear an FFP2 mask throughout the visit or stay.    The following applies to employees:   â¢	The operator may only let employees in if they can show proof of 2G. If one cannot be presented, a valid PCR test must be presented. In the event of a positive test result, admission can still take place if there are at least 48 hours of symptoms after the infection has expired and it can be assumed on the basis of the medical laboratory findings, in particular based on a CT value >30, that there is no longer any risk of infection.  â¢	Employees must wear an FFP2 mask in closed rooms.    The following applies to operators:  â¢	The operator of old people's and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled may only admit residents to new admissions if they can show proof of 2.5G.  â¢	The operator of retirement and nursing homes must offer residents an antigen test for SARS-CoV-2 or a molecular biological test for SARS-CoV-2 at least every seven days, but if they have left the home within this period.  â¢	The operator must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.      **Measures for the entire federal state of Carinthia**  Inpatient residential and care facilities for the elderly  From January 17th, 2022 (until February 2nd, 2022) additional measures will apply in Carinthia for inpatient residential and care facilities for the elderly:    Work:  â¢	2G proof required. If such proof cannot be presented, proof of a negative PCR test that was taken no more than 48 hours ago must be presented. In exceptional cases (maintenance of operations), a negative PCR test can be presented, which must not have been taken more than 72 hours ago.  â¢	In addition, a PCR test must be carried out three times a week after starting work or entering the facility.  â¢	Special rule: "Boosted" people only need to carry out a PCR test once a week after starting work or entering the facility.  â¢	In the event of a positive test result, entry is still permitted if there are no symptoms for at least 48 hours after the infection has expired and it can be assumed on medical grounds, in particular based on a CT value of more than 30, that there is no longer any risk of infection.    Visitors:   â¢	Visitors may only be admitted if they have 2G+ proof, which must not have been issued more than 48 hours ago.  â¢	In the event of a positive test result, entry is still permitted if there are no symptoms for at least 48 hours after the infection has expired and it can be assumed on medical grounds, in particular based on a CT value of more than 30, that there is no longer any risk of infection.    Residents:  â¢	The operator must enable the residents to carry out a PCR test once a week.  Details can be found in the relevant regulation  .    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220130232212/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131105458/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220130232627/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/regionale-zusaetzliche-massnahmen/kaernten/

Retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled    Entering old people's and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled is only permitted under certain conditions:  â¢	Visitor limit: a maximum of two visits are permitted per resident and day, plus a maximum of more  	o	two people per day to accompany underage residents of residential facilities for the disabled,  	o	two people per resident in need of support per day if they perform regular support and care tasks.  	o	Exceptions: Visits as part of palliative care and hospice care, pastoral care and to accompany critical life events.  â¢	If it can be credibly demonstrated that a negative PCR test cannot be presented for reasons of lack of availability, an untimely evaluation or due to the unpredictability of the official activity to be performed, operators may exceptionally admit persons even if they have 3G proof submit. This also applies to operators.  â¢	The planned measures must not be disproportionate or lead to unreasonable hardship.    The following generally applies to visitors:  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show 2G+ proof.  â¢	Exceptions: Accompanying persons of underage residents of inpatient residential facilities of the disabled aid and for visitors of palliative care and hospice patients.  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they wear an FFP2 mask throughout the visit or stay.    The following applies to employees:   â¢	Operators may only let employees in if they can show proof of 2.5G.  â¢	Employees must wear an FFP2 mask in closed rooms.  â¢	This also applies to external service providers, statutory representatives, bodies responsible for care supervision or members of established commissions.    The following applies to operators:  â¢	Operators of old peopleâs and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled may only admit residents to new admissions if they can show proof of 2.5G. If no 2.5G proof can be provided, quarantine or other suitable measures should be implemented in accordance with a Covid-19 prevention concept.  â¢	Operators of retirement and nursing homes must offer residents an antigen test or PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 at least every seven days, but if they have left the home within this period.  â¢	Operators must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.    **Vienna**  Retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled  â¢	Visitors must provide proof of 2G+, whereby the negative PCR test must not be older than 48 hours; A maximum of two visitors per day per resident.  â¢	Employees, owners and operators require 2G proof. If the 2G proof cannot be provided, a negative PCR test must be submitted. In exceptional cases, if it is absolutely necessary to maintain operations, a negative PCR test, which must not have been taken more than 72 hours ago, can be presented. In addition, a PCR test is prescribed twice a week (=professional group screening).  â¢	Owners, operators and employees of inpatient hospitals who have recovered from an illness with the Omicron variant after January 15th, 2022 must present a negative antigen test to an authorized body twice a week for four weeks after the infection has been overcome instead of the PCR tests.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/hh6W3 .[Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/4E6Wl [Coronavirus: current measures]  https://web.archive.org/web/20220201224111/https://www.ris.bka.gv.at/Dokumente/BgblAuth/BGBLA_2022_II_34/BGBLA_2022_II_34.html [4th COVID-19 Measures Ordinance and amendment of the 4th COVID-19 Measures Ordinance (1st amendment to the 4th COVID-19-MV]  https://archive.vn/b1gXo#selection-1205.0-1265.290 [Vienna]  https://archive.vn/UtGXz [Vienna COVID-19 Accompanying Measures Ordinance 2022]

This also applies to operators.  â¢	The planned measures must not be disproportionate or lead to unreasonable hardship.    The following generally applies to visitors:  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show 2G+ proof.  â¢	Exceptions: Accompanying persons of underage residents of inpatient residential facilities for the disabled as well as for visitors of palliative and hospice patients.  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they wear an FFP2 mask throughout the visit or stay. The following applies to operators:  â¢	Operators of old peopleâs and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled may only admit new residents if they can show proof of 2.5G. If no 2.5G proof can be provided, quarantine or other suitable measures should be implemented in accordance with a Covid-19 prevention concept.  â¢	Operators of retirement and nursing homes must offer residents an antigen test or PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 at least every seven days, but if they have left the home within this period.  â¢	Operators must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.    **In Vienna**  Retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled    Visitors must provide proof of 2G+, whereby the negative PCR test must not be older than 48 hours; A maximum of two visitors per day per resident. Retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled  Entering old people's and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled is only permitted under certain conditions:  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show proof of 2G+ (approval no older than 72 hours)  â¢	If it can be credibly demonstrated that a negative PCR test cannot be presented for reasons of lack of availability, an untimely evaluation or due to the unpredictability of the official activity to be performed, operators may exceptionally admit persons even if they have 3G proof submit. This also applies to operators.  â¢	The planned measures must not be disproportionate or lead to unreasonable hardship.    The following generally applies to visitors:  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show 2G+ proof.  â¢	Exceptions: Accompanying persons of underage residents: inside residential facilities for the disabled, for visitors of palliative and hospice patients, as well as pastoral care and to accompany critical life events.  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they wear an FFP2 mask throughout the visit or stay.    The following applies to employees:   â¢	Operators may only let employees in if they can show proof of 2.5G.  â¢	Employees must wear an FFP2 mask in closed rooms.  â¢	This also applies to external service providers, statutory representatives, bodies responsible for care supervision or members of established commissions. If no 2.5G proof can be provided, quarantine or other suitable measures should be implemented in accordance with a Covid-19 prevention concept.  â¢	Operators of retirement and nursing homes must offer residents an antigen test or PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 at least every seven days, but if they have left the home within this period.  â¢	Operators must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220218132709/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/

Retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled    Entering residential homes for the elderly and nursing homes as well as residential homes for the disabled is only permitted under certain conditions:  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show 2G proof and also a valid PCR test (valid for 72 hours), or 2G proof and also an antigen test carried out by an authorized body (valid for 24 hours). .  â¢	If it can be credibly demonstrated that a negative PCR test cannot be presented for reasons of lack of availability, an untimely evaluation or due to the unpredictability of the official activity to be performed, operators may exceptionally admit persons even if they have 3G proof submit. This also applies to operators.  â¢	The planned measures must not be disproportionate or lead to unreasonable hardship.    The following applies to visitors:  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show 2G+ proof.  â¢	Exceptions are given for persons accompanying underage residents of inpatient residential facilities for the disabled, as well as for visits by palliative and hospice patients, for pastoral care and to accompany critical life events.  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they wear an FFP2 mask throughout the visit or stay.    The following applies to employees:   â¢	Operators may only let employees in if they can show proof of 2.5G.  â¢	Employees must wear an FFP2 mask in closed rooms.  â¢	This also applies to external service providers, statutory representatives, bodies responsible for care supervision or members of established commissions.    The following applies to operators:  â¢	Operators of stationary old people's homes and care facilities as well as stationary housing facilities for the disabled may only admit residents to new admissions if they can show proof of 2.5G. If no 2.5G proof can be provided, quarantine or other suitable measures should be implemented in accordance with a Covid-19 prevention concept.  â¢	Operators of inpatient residential and care facilities for the elderly must offer residents an antigen test or PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 at least every seven days, but if they have left the home within this period.  â¢	Operators must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/5egKM [Nationwide measures]  https://web.archive.org/web/20220221202947/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html [Coronavirus: current measures]  https://archive.vn/DibEY [5th amendment to the 4th COVID-19 Measures Ordinance]

COVID-19 Testing    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Azerbaijan? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within one calendar day? Yes  COVID-19 testing is available in Baku. Individuals are responsible for the entire cost of COVID-19 tests and the cost is in the range of 100 AZN.  The labs listed on AZALâs website are accredited by the Management Union of Medical Territorial Units (TABIB) to offer COVID-19 tests.  Test results can be available by email or text message, depending on the procedures of each individual lab.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222003015/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/
No changes found
Effective May 31, masks are not required outdoors, but remain obligatory inside and on public transportation.  Non-compliance with mask mandates can result in fines up to 600 AZN.

Which vaccines are available in Azerbaijan?  According to a Ministry of Health announcement, the Pfizer vaccine is available to citizens 18 years and older at the Baku Health Center and the outpatient clinic of the Central Clinic Hospital.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222003015/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/

Belgium operates a colour code that determines entry protocols based on the country of arrival. (Red(High risk), Yellow(Moderate risk) and Green(Low risk)). Stricter rules apply for countries considered to be Very High Risk.    People from countries categorized as "VERY HIGH RISK COUNTRIES" outside the European Union or Schengen area are not allowed entry into Belgium.     Vaccinated people from ZONES catorized at "RED" outside the European Union or Schengen area are required to get tested before your arrival in Belgium (PCR or RAT), regardless of the length of stay and to get also tested (PCR) on day 1 and 7 after arrival in Belgium. They would also have to stay in quarantine until the negative result of your test on day 1.    Those coming in from a GREEN or ORANGE zone do not need to get tested or quarantine.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220127111112/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/travels/

Belgium operates a colour code that determines entry protocols based on the country of arrival. (Red(High risk), Yellow(Moderate risk) and Green(Low risk)). Stricter rules apply for countries considered to be Very High Risk.    People from countries categorized as "VERY HIGH RISK COUNTRIES" outside the European Union or Schengen area are not allowed entry into Belgium.     Vaccinated people from ZONES catorized at "RED" outside the European Union or Schengen area are required to get tested before your arrival in Belgium (PCR or RAT), regardless of the length of stay and to get also tested (PCR) on day 1 and 7 after arrival in Belgium. They would also have to stay in quarantine until the negative result of your test on day 1.    Those coming in from a GREEN or ORANGE zone do not need to get tested or quarantine.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220127111112/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/travels/

Belgium operates a colour code that determines entry protocols based on the country of arrival. (Red(High risk), Yellow(Moderate risk) and Green(Low risk)). Stricter rules apply for countries considered to be Very High Risk.    Vaccinated people from ZONES catorized at "RED" outside the European Union or Schengen area are required to get tested before your arrival in Belgium (PCR or RAT), regardless of the length of stay and to get also tested (PCR) on day 1 and 7 after arrival in Belgium. They would also have to stay in quarantine until the negative result of your test on day 1.    Those coming in from a GREEN or ORANGE zone do not need to get tested or quarantine.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210045624/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/travels/

Belgium operates a colour code that determines entry protocols based on the country of arrival. There are currently 5 colours: green, orange, red, dark red and grey.    - Those who do not live in Belgium who live a?country or zone that is not very high risk? do not need to get tested or quarantine.     - Those who live in a very high-risk country or zone?inside the European Union or Schengen Area who have a vaccination or recovery certificate do not need to quarantine or get tested. Those who do not have a vaccination or recovery certificate have to get tested (PCR) up to 72 hours before arrival. Those who test positive, must be quarantined and are not allowed to travel. OR get tested (PCR) on arrival and maintain a quarantine until the results are announced. Those who text negative can then end quarantine as soon as they get the test result.    - Those who do not live in Belgium who have been in a very high-risk country outside the EU/Schengen area in the past 14 days are ?not allowed to travel to Belgium.         Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220217212028/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/travels/

Belgium operates a colour code that determines entry protocols based on the country of arrival. There are currently 5 colours: green, orange, red, dark red and grey.    - Those who do not live in Belgium who live a country or zone that is not very high risk do not need to get tested or quarantine.     - Those who live in a very high-risk country or zone inside the European Union or Schengen Area who have a vaccination or recovery certificate do not need to quarantine or get tested. Those who do not have a vaccination or recovery certificate have to get tested (PCR) up to 72 hours before arrival. Those who test positive, must be quarantined and are not allowed to travel. OR get tested (PCR) on arrival and maintain a quarantine until the results are announced. Those who text negative can then end quarantine as soon as they get the test result.    - Those who do not live in Belgium who have been in a very high-risk country outside the EU/Schengen area in the past 14 days are not allowed to travel to Belgium except under some circumstances which are explained here: https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/exemptions/         Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220217212028/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/travels/

Wearing a face mask remains mandatory for everyone in the following areas:    - on public transport from entering the indoor areas of the airport, the station, on the platform or a bus, (pre-)metro, tram, train stop or any other means of transport organised by a public authority. Public transport operators and all bus operators carrying out public transport services are not required to cover their nose and mouth, insofar as the driver is well-isolated in a cabin on the one hand, and a poster and/or sticker indicates to users the reason why the driver is not wearing a mask on the other;  - in the indoor areas of organised collective transport (i.e. transport organised in advance with a clear itinerary or final destination and a vehicle with at least 9+1 seats (passengers + driver)), this does not apply to public transport operators, insofar as the driver is well-isolated in a cabin on the one hand, and a poster and/or sticker indicates to users the reason why the driver is not wearing a mask on the other;  - in establishments and places where close-contact professions are carried out. This applies to service providers and customers where there is direct physical contact between the service provider and the customer or where the distance of 1.5 metres cannot be guaranteed between the service provider and the customer for a duration of at least 15 minutes;  - the publicly accessible areas of companies, associations and services;  the publicly accessible areas of commercial establishments, shops and shopping centres;  libraries, game and multimedia libraries;  - in the indoor areas accessible to the public of establishments belonging to the sports sector, including fitness centres and establishments that may remain open in accordance with Article 7, Â§1 of the Royal Decree, subject to items 11 and 12 below;  - in places of worship and buildings intended for the public practice of non-denominational moral services;  when moving around in public and non-public parts of courthouses and courtrooms and, in other cases, in accordance with the guidelines laid down by the Chairman;  - the publicly accessible areas of government buildings;  establishments and places where catering activities are permitted, both for staff and those customers who are not seated at a table or at the bar;  locations where authorised private gatherings and activities in an organised context take place with more than 50 people indoors or 100 people outdoors;  - venues for events of any size, including mass events, authorised outdoor conferences and authorised sports competitions;  trade fairs, including exhibitions;  - other locations where access is organised in accordance with the Cooperation Agreement of 14 July 2021 with regard to the CST. *the indoor areas of schools and educational institutions;  - the indoor areas of the after-school care facilities for primary school children.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220127105912/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/

Conducting face-to-face group classes for children in language centers, educational centers, personal development support centers and other training centers and schools is allowed provided at a physical distance of at least 1.5 m and not more than 5 people in a room, wearing protective face masks, hand hygiene, regular airing every hour and disinfection. Restrictions do not apply to special education support centers.  The students may conduct face-to-face classes in municipalities with a 14-day morbidity of over 500 per 100 000 population if the following conditions are met: (a) a field organization has been set up for a COVID-19 study with rapid antigen tests once a week (on the first school day of the week) for students in the relevant classes (attending face-to-face training) and twice a week for pedagogical and non-teaching staff involved in on-site training, except those who have valid documents for vaccination, illness or testing; b) in case of disagreement of the parents / guardians / custodians to conduct a study for COVID-19, the student is not admitted to face-to-face training and is provided with the opportunity for distance learning in an electronic environment; (c) exceptionally, individual activities (individual lessons, consultations, ongoing assessment tests, examinations, etc.) may be conducted without applying the requirement of letter "a" for students if the individual activities are conducted outside the time of the present learning process of the classes.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206194450/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Suspension of group adult classes.  Face-to-face group classes for children in language centers, educational centers, personal development support centers and other training centers and schools is allowed provided at a physical distance of at least 1.5 m and not more than 5 people in a room, wearing protective face masks, hand hygiene, regular airing every hour and disinfection. Restrictions do not apply to special education support centers.  https://archive.vn/C1xRK

Employers and appointment bodies in all administrations within the meaning of Art. 1 of the Administration Act organise the work process of the employees, as: (a) establish working hours with variable limits and the start of the working day between 7.30 and 10.00, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work; (b) assign remote work to at least 50% of staff, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work.   Employers in hospitals, complex oncology centres, dialysis centres, hospices and nursing homes organise the work process by admitting to work only employees with valid documents for vaccination, illness or testing within the meaning of this order. The employer can arrange for a COVID-19 study to be performed with rapid on-site antigen testing. A protocol shall be drawn up for the conducted examination, in which the names of the employee, the result of the test and the date of its performance shall be entered. The protocol is signed by the employer and the respondents. The results are valid up to 48 hours after sampling.  Visits to libraries, museums, galleries, cinemas, theatres, circus performances, concerts and other indoor performances, fitness centres, sports halls and clubs, swimming pools and complexes, balneotherapy (medical SPA) centres, SPA centres, wellness centres and thalassotherapy centres, gambling halls, casinos and food and entertainment establishments within the meaning of Art. 124 of the Tourism Act, including those to the places of accommodation, shopping malls, shops with a net retail area of ??over 300 square metres, bazaars and indoor exhibitions shall be suspended. Exceptions are allowed for shops offering mainly groceries, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet shops, banks, postal and courier service providers, insurers, payment service providers and telecommunications operators' offices, whether they are stand-alone or located in a shopping centre type Mall. An exception is allowed for medical establishments and vaccination points located on the territory of shopping centres. These anti-epidemic measures may not be applied if: (a) 100% of the staff at the site / persons involved in the event have been vaccinated or have suffered from COVID-19 or have a test result certified by valid vaccination, disease or test documents, and b) the manager of the site / the organiser of the event has made a decision and has created the necessary organisation for admission to the site, respectively of the event only to persons who: (aa) have been vaccinated or have suffered from COVID-19, certified by valid vaccination or illness documents, or (bb) present a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction test for COVID-19 or a rapid antigen test (up to 48 hours before entry into the site / event) up to 72 hours prior to entry into the site / event, certified by a valid document or certificate presence of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2. (c) the conditions in points (aa) and (bb) do not apply to persons under the age of 18.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206194450/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Employers and recruitment bodies to organize the work process of employees in remote form (distance work / home work), where possible, allowing the presence of at most 50% of the staff. Employers in hospitals, complex oncology centers, dialysis centers, hospices and nursing homes organize the work process by admitting to work only employees with valid documents for vaccination, illness or testing within the meaning of this order. The employer can arrange for a COVID-19 study to be performed with rapid on-site antigen testing.  https://archive.vn/C1xRK

The holding of all mass events, such as music and other festivals, fairs, folklore initiatives and others of such nature, shall be suspended. Visits to libraries, museums, galleries, cinemas, theatres, circus performances, concerts and other indoor performances are suspended. Sports competitions are allowed without an audience. Visits to fitness centres, sports halls and clubs, swimming pools and complexes, balneotherapy (medical SPA) centres, SPA centres, wellness centres and thalassotherapy centres are suspended. Visits to gambling halls, casinos and food and entertainment establishments within the meaning of Art. 124 of the Tourism Act, including those to the places of accommodation. Visits to shopping malls, shops with a net retail area of ??over 300 square metres, bazaars and indoor exhibitions shall be suspended. Exceptions are allowed for shops offering mainly groceries, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet shops, banks, postal and courier service providers, insurers, payment service providers and telecommunications operators' offices, whether they are stand-alone or located in a shopping centre type Mall. An exception is allowed for medical establishments and vaccination points located on the territory of shopping centres. The conducting of organised excursions and group visits to tourist sites in the country is suspended.  The above anti-epidemic measures may not be applied if: (a) 100% of the staff at the site / persons involved in the event have been vaccinated or have suffered from COVID-19 or have a test result certified by valid vaccination, disease or test documents, and b) the manager of the site / the organiser of the event has made a decision and has created the necessary organisation for admission to the site, respectively of the event only to persons who: (aa) have been vaccinated or have suffered from COVID-19, certified by valid vaccination or illness documents, or (bb) present a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction test for COVID-19 or a rapid antigen test (up to 48 hours before entry into the site / event) up to 72 hours prior to entry into the site / event, certified by a valid document or certificate presence of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2. (c) the conditions in points (aa) and (bb) do not apply to persons under the age of 18.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206194450/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Visits to fitness centers, sports halls and clubs, swimming pools and complexes, balneotherapy (medical SPA) centers, SPA centers, wellness centers and thalassotherapy centers are suspended. Visits to gambling halls, casinos and food and entertainment establishments within the meaning of Art. 124 of the Tourism Act, including those to the places of accommodation. Unitl 31 January, UK nationals (and their family members) travelling directly from the UK, a European Union member state, a European Economic Area country or Switzerland (even if that country is also in the red zone) are eligible to enter Bulgaria, but you must provide the following pieces of COVID-19 documentation in order to be allowed entry: a vaccination certificate (Bulgaria will accept either certificate of completion of a two dose vaccine course (Pfizer-BioNTech, AstraZeneca, Novavax, Moderna, Covishield, Sinopharm, Sinovac, Sputnik) or a certificate of receipt of a one dose vaccine (Janssen, Johnson & Johnson). In both cases immunization must have been completed 14 days prior to arrival; or evidence of past COVID-19 infection (a test result certificate, in English, showing a positive test result from either a PCR or rapid antigen test dated at least 11 days, but no more than 180 days, before arrival in Bulgaria). You must also provide: a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before entry - this should include name, date of birth, details of the medical institution and date and time of the sample, and should be in English.  Until 31 January, Bulgarian nationals and permanent and long-term residents, as well as their family members who present only one of the listed documents â a certificate of vaccination or recovery or a negative PCR test, are allowed to travel but, must self-isolate for 10 days upon arrival. This 10-day quarantine period can be shortened if they perform a PCR test no earlier than 72 hours after their arrival in Bulgaria. If the result is negative, quarantine will be lifted from the day following the registration of the result.  Until 31 January, Bulgarian nationals and permanent and long-term residents, as well as their family members who do not present any of the listed documents â a certificate of vaccination or recovery or a negative PCR test, will be allowed to enter Bulgaria. However, they will be required to complete a mandatory 10-day quarantine which cannot be ended early through testing.  Only Bulgarian nationals and permanent and long-term residents, as well as their family members, will be allowed to enter from the following countries: South Africa, Mozambique, Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia, Eswatini and Zimbabwe. They will be subject to a mandatory 10-day self-isolation and a mandatory antigen testing upon entry.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206205624/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bulgaria/entry-requirements

As of 1st February 2022. All travellers arriving to Bulgaria from a Green, Orange or Red Zone country, regardless of their citizenship, can enter without quarantine if they present an EU Digital COVID Certificate showing that the person has been vaccinated against COVID-19, has received a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or antigen COVID test result conducted up to 72 hours before entering the country, or has recovered from COVID-19. Similar documents which contain the same data as the EU digital certificate, such as a U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Vaccination Record Card, are also accepted.    All travellers arriving to Bulgaria from a Dark Red Zone country, regardless of their citizenship, can enter Bulgaria by presenting an EU Digital COVID Certificate showing that the person has been vaccinated against COVID-19 or has recovered from COVID-19 or a similar document which contain the same data as the EU digital certificate together with a negative PCR test result conducted up to 72 hours before entering the country.    Persons travelling from a dark red zone country who present a valid digital EU COVID certificate for vaccination for an additional (booster) dose or equivalent or similar document do not need to present a negative PCR result from 72 hours before entry into the country.    Some exceptions apply with regards to the requirement for a valid COVID certificate or equivalent.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206194450/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206201619/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206204105/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/3233

Under the Bulgarian Ministry of Health order, countries are classified as Green, Orange, Red, or Dark Red Zones based on their COVID-19 risk. The current classification of countries as Green, Orange, Red, and Dark Red Zones is listed on the bg.usembassy site. No countries classify as green zone. Persons who present an EU Digital COVID Certificate showing that the person has had a booster dose, or a similar document which contain the same data as the EU digital certificate, do not need to present a negative PCR test result to enter the country. Bulgarian citizens and holders of permanent, long-term, or continuous residence in Bulgaria, who do not present any of the above documents, will be quarantined for a period of 10 days at home or in another place of accommodation, in which the person has indicated that he/she will reside, with a recommendation issued by the Director of the respective Regional Health Inspectorate or a Deputy Director.  https://archive.vn/7Sbkz

Any person who has made contact within 48 hours before and up to 14 days after the onset of symptoms in a patient should be considered when determining close contacts in a confirmed case of COVID-19. If the confirmed case is asymptomatic, contact is any person who has been in contact with the case within 48 hours before up to 14 days after taking the sample that led to the laboratory confirmation. All close contacts of a confirmed case of COVID-19, at the discretion of an epidemiologist from RHI, are quarantined at home or elsewhere for accommodation and medical supervision for 7 -day period, as of the last contact with the sick person. The monitoring of the health condition of each contact person is carried out by the general practitioner or the respective regional health inspectorate.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206212409/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/kontaktno-litse

Any person who has made contact within 48 hours before and up to 14 days after the onset of symptoms in a patient should be considered when determining close contacts in a confirmed case of COVID-19. If the confirmed case is asymptomatic, contact is any person who has been in contact with the case within 48 hours before up to 14 days after taking the sample that led to the laboratory confirmation.    Close contacts who have recovered as confirmed cases of COVID-19 are considered to be at low risk for SARS-CoV-2 transmission and are not subject to mandatory quarantine for a period of three months from laboratory confirmation of infection, except in cases where they work with at-risk populations (adults, people with chronic illnesses and immunosuppressive conditions) or live in places at high risk of infection as specialized social care institutions or prisons. In the case of contact with a confirmed case after the expiry of this period, the contact person should be considered as a close contact if he meets the above conditions.  https://archive.vn/Q1lSK

Policy change from maximum of 50 people to 30 people.    The new Order , which is in force as of today, January 13, 2021. year, the number of persons who can stay indoors at the same time from the previous 50 was reduced to 30, while more than 100 people can stay outdoors.  All gatherings within the stated limits must take place in a space that allows a mandatory physical distance of at least 2 meters between persons (except members of the same household).  Exceptionally, the new Order allows the organization of larger gatherings indoors and outdoors, provided that the size of the space allows the implementation of hygienic and epidemiological measures, but not more than 60 people indoors or 200 people outdoors, provided that all participants together have a negative antigen test (not older than 24 hours) or a PCR test (not older than 48 hours) or a certificate of overcoming COVID-19 (not older than 4 months) or a certificate of completed vaccination (not older than 6 months after receiving the second vaccine doses, ie 9 months after receiving the third vaccine dose).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220115120320/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih

CONDITIONS FOR ENTRY TO BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA         (Article 2)    A foreigner who meets conditions for entry to BiH prescribed by Law on Aliens, may enter BiH if he/she at the BiH Border Crossing Points presents any of the following:    negative PCR test or rapid antigen test on SARS-CoV-2, not older than 48 hours if he/she comes from an European country, and if he/she comes from another country, not older than 72 hours until arrival at the border crossing point ofBosnia and Herzegovina,    certificate that a person has received the second dose of vaccine for COVID-19 before more than 14 days before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH or has received one dose before 14 days and more before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH, if it is a single dose vaccine,    certificate issued by doctor showing that he/she has recovered from COVID-19 in the previous period from 14 to 180 days until the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220113193549/http://www.granpol.gov.ba/Content/Read/76?title=Stranci&lang=en

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in BiH? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Private and public clinics throughout BiH perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test and current prices are roughly 100 convertible marks (km) for PCR and 40km for antigen.  Turnaround of results and availability of testing appointments vary based on the city yet clinics in most large cities have testing options daily and return results within 24 hours.  A list of clinics known to provide COVID-19 testing in BiH can be found on our website here  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) test symptomatic individuals regardless of nationality, free of charge. To arrange a test, contact your cantonâs health center for additional guidance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220114112145/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Schools  Compulsory schools and upper secondary schools (e.g. baccalaureate and vocational schools), federal high school and vocational college final exams and continuing education: Masks must be worn in indoor areas of upper secondary schools. All other measures for compulsory schools and upper secondary schools are the responsibility of the cantons.    Tertiary level (e.g. universities, universities of applied sciences and colleges of higher education) and continuing education: Access to certain educational offerings and exams in this area is limited to people who are vaccinated or recovered or have a certificate for a negative test result (3G). Masks must be worn. You will find further details in the explanatory notes to Art. 19a of the Ordinance on Measures during the Special Situation to combat the COVID-19 Epidemic.    Recreational courses: The rules for events apply, i.e. basically the mask and certificate requirement (vaccinated or recovered, 2G) in indoor areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207162650/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

Work  Recommendation to work from home: Working from home is recommended in all areas where it is possible to work from home without disproportionate effort.    COVID certificate: Employers may check whether their employees are vaccinated or recovered or have a certificate for a negative test result (3G) if this is necessary for deciding on appropriate precautionary measures or for implementing testing concepts. The information on immunity status or the test result may not be used for any other purpose. Employees must be consulted on the use of the certificate and the measures derived from this, and these must be documented in writing. On data protection grounds, employers must use the âlight certificateâ with minimised data wherever possible.    Masks compulsory indoors: Masks are compulsory for all employees in indoor areas where several people are present. Exceptions apply in situations where a mask cannot be worn for safety reasons or owing to the nature of the activity as well as to people who cannot wear a mask for medical reasons. In particular, there is no exception to the mask-wearing requirement if it is an establishment in which employees meet the 2G+ requirements (vaccinated/recovered within last 4 months or vaccinated/recovered with negative test).    Protection in the workplace: Information can be found (in German, French and Italian) on the page Precautionary measures and on the page People at especially high risk.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207162650/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

Events  Indoors    Access to indoor events for people aged 16 and over is basically restricted to people who are vaccinated or recovered (2G).    Exempt from this COVID certificate requirement are:    Religious ceremonies, funerals, events that fall within the scope of the normal activities and services of public authorities, political events and self-help groups with up to 50 people. For these indoor events, masks must be worn, the consumption of food and drinks is banned.  Blood donation campaigns are not considered events and are therefore not subject to the COVID certificate requirement. The current precautionary measures continue to apply to these campaigns.  Basically masks must be worn for all events indoors. Where neither wearing masks nor compulsory seating is possible, only vaccinated or recovered people who can present a certificate for a negative test result (2G+) are admitted.    You will find more detailed information on the various areas of application of the COVID certificate and the exceptions on the Use of the COVID certificate page.    Outdoors    At outdoor events, access for people aged 16 and over is also restricted to people who are vaccinated or recovered (2G). The organiser can voluntarily limit access to vaccinated or recovered people who also have a certificate for a negative test result (2G+).Access restrictions can be waived if not more than 300 people are admitted and guests do not dance. Precise details may be found on the Precautionary measures page.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207162650/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

Rule indoors without certificate: A maximum of 30 people is allowed if everyone is vaccinated or recovered. As soon as one person is present who is not vaccinated or recovered and is aged over 16, only up to 10 people may gather.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125075513/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

Public transport is open with mask wearing a legal requirement    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125075513/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

There are no stay at home orders    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125075513/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

There are no restrictions in place for travel into different Cantons     https://web.archive.org/web/20220125075513/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

Who is not permitted to enter Switzerland?  Foreign nationals without proof of a recognised vaccination (see question Â«How can I prove that I am vaccinated?Â») seeking to travel to Switzerland from a SEM high-risk country for a stay here of up to three months without a visa and who do not meet any of the requirements under Â«Who is permitted to enter Switzerland?Â» are not permitted to enter Switzerland. These persons include:    Persons who wish to obtain services in Switzerland;  Tourists, visitors and participants in events;  Persons who wish to come to Switzerland for medical treatment that has not yet begun or that is not regarded as urgently required;  Persons seeking employment or who have been invited for a job interview in Switzerland;  Persons who wish to submit an application for a residence permit.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220164905/https://www.sem.admin.ch/sem/en/home/sem/aktuell/faq-einreiseverweigerung.html#-1871257744

7/2/22  As of 20.12, the Swiss government pays for tests (both anti-gen and PCR tests) that are needed for a COVID-19 certificate.    Test costs for certificates will be covered again  The Federal Council has also decided that the costs of certain Covid-19 tests that lead to a Covid certificate will be covered again in future. In doing so, he is implementing a parliamentary decision in the Covid 19 law. Rapid antigen tests and saliva PCR pool tests are to be paid for. Self-tests, individual PCR tests and antibody tests are not paid for. The costs of individual PCR tests for people with symptoms of illness, for contact persons and after positive pool samples are also covered. The new test cost system will apply from tomorrow, Saturday, December 18, 2021. From January 17, 2022, everyone who takes part in repetitive tests must also be able to obtain a test certificate.    Only one test upon entry for vaccinated and recovered people  After consulting the cantons, the Federal Council has also adjusted the test regime upon entry, which will apply from Monday, December 20, 2021. Before entering Switzerland, in addition to PCR tests that are not are older than 72 hours, rapid antigen tests that are not older than 24 hours are also accepted. The obligation to have a second test 4 to 7 days after entering Switzerland is waived for vaccinated and recovered people.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211221065541/https://www.admin.ch/gov/de/start/dokumentation/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-86544.html

7/2/22  Entry where a certificate is required has strict criteria around the process placed upon venue owners.    Entry checks with the COVID certificate  When letting people in, it is important that event organisers check the validity of the COVID certificate via COVID Certificate Check and always check against matching photo identification (e.g. ID card, passport, driving licence, residence permit, student card). In addition, organisers of large-scale events must obtain a cantonal permit. The COVID certificate is the only permissible document for entry. This applies to both the Swiss COVID certificate and to recognised foreign certificates (e.g. the EU Digital COVID Certificate). Youâll find more information for checkers and issuers on the COVID certificate on the corresponding page.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220125075513/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

Cyprus is changing its compulsory quarantine rules for school children in an effort to keep pupils in school amid surging coronavirus infections, the country's health minister said Wednesday.    Under the new system, schoolkids who were in close contact with classmates who test positive will no longer face compulsory quarantine. Instead, they must undergo either a rapid or a self-test for five consecutive days while continuing to attend school â so long as they test negative.    https://web.archive.org/https://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/cyprus-swaps-student-quarantine-days-virus-tests-82221285

All pupils of primary and secondary education will undertake weekly testing at school.   Masks must be worn when there are more than 50 people in a room.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220214182120/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/education/high-schools

As of February 10, the restrictions for visiting restaurants and other services cease to apply.  For those who are not vaccinated, exceptions may apply for visiting healthcare, social, and other similar facilities.    Masks must be worn in public indoors spaces.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214183024/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/infection-and-general-measures/o-n-t-system-vaccination-past-disease-test   https://web.archive.org/web/20220214183623/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/face-masks-and-respirators/workplace

Public events can take place, maximum of 1,000 spectators may be present. Spectators must be seated.   All spectators must have a respirator on at all times without an exhalation valve of min. class FFP2 (KN95 / N95).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214183933/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/culture/festivals

Public and private events can take place with a limit of 100 participants.  During social events indoors, it is mandatory to wear a respirator without an exhalation valve min. class FFP2 (KN95 / N95).  If the event takes place outdoors, this obligation applies if the celebrations are attended by more than 30 people and at the same time it is not possible to keep a distance of at least 1.5 meters from other people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214184126/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/culture/social-events
Masks must be worn inside public transports    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214184331/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/face-masks-and-respirators/public-transport-taxi
No measure found  https://web.archive.org/web/20220214184641/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/free-movement-people/measures-free-movement
No measure found  https://web.archive.org/web/20220214184641/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/free-movement-people/measures-free-movement

Different regulations applies to different countries. Most travelers must be tested, except those who are vaccinated. Travelers coming from a country listed as dark red must quarantine until they receive the results of their tests taken between 5 and 7 days after their arrival, if they are not vaccinated. All travelers must fill an Arrival Form.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220214184800/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/foreigners/possibilities-and-obligations-foreigners-when-entering-cz

This compensation applies to cases where employees are ordered to quarantine or to be isolated due to COVID-19. The amount of the support is set at 80% of eligible costs (compensation of wages paid to employees + the corresponding amount of statutory contributions), but a maximum of CZK 39,000 per employee and month. For employees, this means that they are in obstacles and receive a wage compensation of 60% of average earnings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214185240/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/compensation/antivirus-plus-forced-limitations-service-operation-and-quarantine

No evidence that the debt relief policy of 2020 is still in place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220214190137/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/
There is an updated government website to provide information  https://web.archive.org/web/20220214031207/https://covid.gov.cz/

Tests are available for all, they can be free of charge with a doctor request, paid for by the health insurance under certain conditions, or if none of the conditions apply, self-paid.  https://archive.vn/Hq4wM

Self-reporting is recommended and tracing centers are organizing the tracing effort.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220214191118/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/infection-and-general-measures/how-does-tracing-work

Masks are required in most indoors public spaces and are recommended in outdoors public space where social distancing cannot be kept.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220214191245/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/face-masks-and-respirators/indoors

Vaccination is available to all over 5 and is funded either by public health insurance or self-paid.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220214191516/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/register-vaccination/vaccination-nutshell

For all, preventive measures must be followed and masks must be worn inside care facilities.  For those non-vaccinated, a negative test or a proof of covid-recovery is required to access the facility.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220214191740/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/hospitals-and-sanitary-facilities/visits-social-facilities

Vaccination is available to all over 5 and is funded either by public health insurance or self-paid.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220214191516/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/register-vaccination/vaccination-nutshell
Vaccination is available for those over 5 years old.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220214191516/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/register-vaccination/vaccination-nutshell

Vaccination is paid either by EU public health insurance or must be self-paid by those who do not have this insurance.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220214191516/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/register-vaccination/vaccination-nutshell

Still restricted in at least one area. The general decree for the Free State of Thuringia for day-care facilities, schools, further youth welfare and for sport is valid until 20 February 2022. In the pdf it states that if children cannot be tested or are not vaccinated, then they are to remain home and use distance learning. As this does not apply to all levels, it is coded as a 2 rather than a 3. https://web.archive.org/web/20220204202503/https://bildung.thueringen.de/ministerium/coronavirus

The federal and state governments agreed on 24 January that the current corona rules should continue to apply. Indoor clubs and discotheques will remain closed until further notice and dance performances will be banned. Indoor clubs and discotheques will remain closed until further notice and dance performances will be banned. https://web.archive.org/web/20220204203141/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

no changes. Indoor clubs and discotheques will remain closed until further notice and dance performances will be banned.: https://web.archive.org/web/20220211154243/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

Facilities and events of cultural and leisure activities (such as cinemas, theatres, etc.) may only be visited by vaccinated and convalescents (2G). This applies nationwide and is independent of the incidence. There are exceptions for people who cannot be vaccinated or for whom there is no general vaccination recommendation. The exact regulations are issued by the federal states in their state ordinances. https://web.archive.org/web/20220204203141/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

For large national events, the federal governmanet follows the local regulations issues by the federal states & required the states to harmonize them. https://web.archive.org/web/20220204203141/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724 On Feb 2, the federal states stated that they will allow up to 10,000 spectators at major outdoor events such as Bundesliga soccer games & also allow up to 4,000 participants in indoor spaces.  Masks must be worn, and proof of vaccination or recovery, as well as a booster shot or negative test status, depending on the state, will also be required. https://web.archive.org/web/20220203152543/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/germany-passes-10-million-mark-covid-19-infections-2022-02-02/
no changes: https://web.archive.org/web/20220211154243/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

In order to slow down the Omikron variant, private gatherings of vaccinated and convalescents are only allowed with a maximum of ten people. In order to slow down the Omikron variant, private gatherings of vaccinated and convalescents are only allowed with a maximum of ten people. https://web.archive.org/web/20220204203141/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

In order to slow down the Omikron variant, private gatherings of vaccinated and convalescents are only allowed with a maximum of ten people. Private meetings in public or private spaces attended by persons who have not been vaccinated or recovered shall be limited to one's own household and to a maximum of two other persons in another household.  Children up to the age of 14 do not count.  no changes https://web.archive.org/web/20220211154243/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

In public transport and regional and long-distance trains, the 3G rule applies in addition to the mask requirement. If passengers have not been vaccinated or recovered, they must carry proof of a negative corona rapid test when using a means of transport. At the start of the journey, the test acceptance must not be more than 24 hours ago. https://web.archive.org/web/20220204203141/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

In public transport and regional and long-distance trains, the 3G rule applies in addition to the mask requirement. If passengers have not been vaccinated or recovered, they must carry proof of a negative corona rapid test when using a means of transport. At the start of the journey, the test acceptance must not be more than 24 hours ago. https://web.archive.org/web/20220211154243/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724
It remains necessary to significantly reduce contacts. https://web.archive.org/web/20220204203141/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

Facilities and events of cultural and leisure activities (such as cinemas, theatres, etc.) may only be visited by vaccinated and convalescents (2G). This applies nationwide and is independent of the incidence. There are exceptions for people who cannot be vaccinated or for whom there is no general vaccination recommendation. https://web.archive.org/web/20220211154243/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

The 3G obligation applies to air transport, public transport and long-distance public transport.  In addition to the mask requirement, the 3G obligation applies to all passengers or passengers as well as to control and service personnel.  Those who have not been vaccinated or recovered must carry proof of a negative corona test (not a self-test). https://web.archive.org/web/20220119192803/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/3g-regel-in-bus-und-bahn-1983736
no changes: https://web.archive.org/web/20220211154243/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

Persons entering must complete a digital entry registration. They also have to provide a negative test result or proof of immunity, and comply with quarantine regulations depending on the place of departure. A travel ban is in place for countries with widespread occurrence of SARS-CoV-2 virus variants of concern (referred to as areas of variant of concern).  https://web.archive.org/web/20220204204955/https://www.germany.info/us-en/coronavirus/2317268

Following the recommendation of the European Commission, the German authorities have decided to shorten the validity of vaccination certificates to 270 days.  The new rule on the vaccination passes entered into force on February 1 and affects everyone travelling within the EU. https://web.archive.org/web/20220207135111/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/new-rules-now-apply-for-entering-germany/
no changes since January: https://web.archive.org/web/20220211161808/https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/en/coronavirus/2317268

For small and medium-sized businesses, the self-employed and non-profit organizations, there is a bridging aid for sales declines during the coronavirus pandemic. In addition, newly founded companies that are less than five years old can make corona relief loans. In addition, newly founded companies that are less than five years old can make corona relief loans  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207150507/https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/informieren/arbeit-und-studium/arbeiten-und-corona/

The current short-time allowance regulation expires on 31 March. The Federal Cabinet has therefore initiated [updated] regulations will subsequently apply until 30 June 2022. The requirements for access to short-time allowance will remain reduced. https://web.archive.org/web/20220211155508/https://www.deutschland.de/en/news/german-federal-government-informs-about-the-corona-crisis

more generous repayment periods for Corona emergency aid (first program from spring 2020) are now possible. In addition, the repayment of loans (KfW entrepreneur loan, ERP start-up loan with liability exemption, KfW quick loan) remains flexible in the KfW special programme. Thus, the subsequent granting of a second repayment-free year for loans with only one repayment-free start-up year is still unbureaucratically possible and can be applied for via the respective house bank. The scheme, which was originally limited to 31.12.2021, has been extended until 17.06.2022 (application received by KfW). https://archive.vn/xXNzy

while generally available, the federal government has stated that "In the future, PCR tests will be concentrated on risk groups and employees who care for and treat them." https://web.archive.org/web/20220204203141/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

Lauterbach announced a change in the testing regulation this week. Among other things, there will continue to be prioritisation for those working in nursing homes and in the medical field. Furthermore, he said, it was planned that all people would also be entitled to PCR retesting after a positive Corona rapid test. In this way, one would have "an efficient, but also safe system" of testing. https://web.archive.org/web/20220211155508/https://www.deutschland.de/en/news/german-federal-government-informs-about-the-corona-crisis
Germany promotes and utilizes a mobile phone application called Corona-Warn-App to enable contact tracing. https://web.archive.org/web/20220207140048/https://www.coronawarn.app/en/

In principle, masks are mandatory for all citizens wherever people come together in a confined space. In schools, masks are mandatory for all grade levels. When using public transport, the use of FFP2 masks is strongly recommended. https://web.archive.org/web/20220204203141/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

widely available at vaccination centers and doctors offices. soon to be offered at pharmacies: https://web.archive.org/web/20220207140934/https://www.deutschland.de/en/news/coronavirus-in-germany-information

Vaccines are becoming more widely accessible:  Since 8 February, pharmacies have also been able to offer vaccinations - appropriately trained pharmacists are then allowed to vaccinate. https://web.archive.org/web/20220211155508/https://www.deutschland.de/en/news/german-federal-government-informs-about-the-corona-crisis

Residents of old people's homes and nursing homes, dormitories for people with disabilities and other particularly vulnerable groups require special protection. By 15 March 2022, employees of clinics, nursing homes and similar institutions must provide proof of vaccination or convalescence.  All visitors and employees must present a negative test certificate on a daily basis. This also applies to vaccinated people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220204203141/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724
no changes until mandates take effect on 15 March: https://web.archive.org/web/20220211154243/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

National Vaccination Strategy was and is the basis for this. Among other things, it outlines the fair distribution of corona vaccines and the organization of the COVID-19 vaccination campaign in different phases and prioritizations: In the first phase, people at high risk and exposed parts of the population could be vaccinated â mainly in vaccination centers or by mobile vaccination teams. On 7 June 2021, vaccination priority was lifted in Germany. https://web.archive.org/web/20220207150507/https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/basiswissen-zum-impfen/die-nationale-impfstrategie/

all citizens aged 12 and over can arrange a vaccination appointment: https://web.archive.org/web/20220207150507/https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/basiswissen-zum-impfen/die-nationale-impfstrategie/

The federal government procures and finances all vaccines used in Germany. https://web.archive.org/web/20220207150507/https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/basiswissen-zum-impfen/die-nationale-impfstrategie/

While in school, Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately. Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to get tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 weeks.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120181034/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

There are no restrictions from February 1, but there are a number of recommendations to prevent infection. People with symptoms of COVID-19 are advised to self-isolate and be PCR-tested as soon as possible. Pupils with symptoms of COVID-19 should be kept separate from the other students and staff until they can be picked up or sent home.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053301/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations
No change in policy. Restrictions were lifted on February 1    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220217215312/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations
No change in policy. Restrictions were lifted on February 1    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220217215312/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

It is adviced to work at home extensively in both public and private workplaces and that meetings, seminars etc. are held virtually.  It is adviced to cancel major social events at workplaces.  Discos and nightclubs are closed. Bars must close at 11pm    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120181034/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

There are no longer any recommendations to work from home in either public or private workplaces. Public and private employers are encouraged to continuously assess the situation and arrange the workplaces according to local infection conditions and the physical conditions in the workplace.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053301/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

There is no assembly ban or any restrictions on how many spectators may attend cultural and sporting events. Organizers of activities where many people gather standing indoors at the same time, and where there may therefore be a particularly high risk of the spread of infection, may consider taking steps to minimize the risk of infection in February. For an example this can be done by the organizer encouraging or facilitating that the participants are tested, or that an increased distance is operated at the event.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053301/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

People are fully vaccinated or previously infected and able to document this, for example with a corona passport,  can enter from all countries without test or self-isolation.    FOR THE UNVACCINATED OR THOSE WHO WERE PREVIOUSLY UNINFECTED:    - Entry from countries in EU/Schengen: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from COVID-19 risk countries: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from all other countries (high risk countries): A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry within 24 hours after entry. Furthermore, there is self-isolation for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival. Certain travellers (e.g. children under 15) are exempt from test and isolation requirements.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053540/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules
