From 1 February 2022 there are no longer any restrictions in the social and elderly area. Thus there are no longer a requirement for corona passport for visitors etc. and requirements for the use of face mask or shield for visitors, etc. and employees on social services, etc.     If possible it is urged to continue arrangements for the display of corona passport and for the use of face mask/shield in nursing homes and social services with vulnerable residents/users. It is also urged with a continued focus on the test effort in relation to employees in the elderly care and on social services as well as visitors to nursing homes and social services.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053301/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

In general education, masks are recommended but covid-certificates are not mandatory.  In informal education and catering establishments, students must either be vaccinated, recovered or present a negative test (tests are accepted only for those under 18).   https://web.archive.org/web/20220211105524/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/education-pre-schools-hobby-education-sport-continuous-education/restrictions-in-education-youth-work-hobby-and-sports-activities

All persons 18 years of age and older must present a COVID certificate proving vaccination or recovery in order to participate in activities taking place in checked public spaces. A COVID certificate has to be presented to participate in sports, training, youth work, hobby activities and informal education, refresher training; at sports competitions, and sports and exercise events; in saunas, spas, water parks and swimming pools; at public meetings and events, including at the theatre, at the cinema, at a concert (including a church concert), at a conference; at museums and exhibition facilities; at entertainment services; at catering establishments in order to eat and drink on the premises.    For everyone, masks are mandatory in public spaces indoors and distance working is recommended.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220130231121/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions

Public meetings and events are allowed but participants who are 18 years old and older have to prove that they do not pose an infection risk by presenting a COVID certificate stating vaccination or recovery.  For children of 12 of 18, negative tests are accepted for their COVID certificate.  Provided that the organiser ensures that the infection risk status of all the participants is checked, up to 1000 people may participate indoors and up to 2 000 people outdoors.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220211105944/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions

All persons 18 years of age and older must present a COVID certificate proving vaccination or recovery in order to participate in activities taking place in checked public spaces. A COVID certificate has to be presented to participate in sports, training, youth work, hobby activities and informal education, refresher training; at sports competitions, and sports and exercise events; in saunas, spas, water parks and swimming pools; at public meetings and events, including at the theatre, at the cinema, at a concert (including a church concert), at a conference; at museums and exhibition facilities; at entertainment services; at catering establishments in order to eat and drink on the premises.    For everyone, masks are mandatory in public spaces indoors and distance working is recommended.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220130231121/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions
Masks must be worn in public transport  https://web.archive.org/web/20220121184838/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/public-services-and-everyday-life/public-transport-within-estonia
No stay at home requirement  https://web.archive.org/web/20220107031211/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/restrictions-in-everyday-life
No restriction  https://web.archive.org/web/20220107031211/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/restrictions-in-everyday-life

Depending of the country of origin, the list of requirement changes. Travelers might have to get tested, self-isolate and might need to present an imperial reason to be allowed to enter Estonia (work, studying, family reasons, or under a special permit). Those who are fully vaccinated are exempt from these measures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211120908/https://www.kriis.ee/en/travelling-crossing-state-border/travelling-estonia/who-subject-restrictions
No support, except sick leave.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220212100202/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/incapacity-benefit-payments---sick-days-care-leave
No relief found  https://web.archive.org/web/20220212100202/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/incapacity-benefit-payments---sick-days-care-leave
A government website keep the public informed  https://web.archive.org/web/20220130231121/https://www.kriis.ee/en/

It is possible to test for the coronavirus both for free (with a referral) and by paying. Free testing is provided for people who are symptomatic. It is possible to get a referral to testing by calling the Family Doctor.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220212100809/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/testing-for-the-virus
Contact tracing is done with the HOIA mobile app.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220212101134/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/hoia-mobile-app

A protective mask is obligatory in public indoor spaces (including rooms where COVID certificate is checked, e.g. cinema, theatre, events, trainings etc). Wearing a mask is not obligatory in activities where it is not possible, for instance, in direct sports and when coming in contact with water, as well as when eating on the premises of restaurants.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212203725/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/personal-protection-equipment---masks-and-similar

All residents of Estonia from the age of 12 are recommended to get vaccinated for free against COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220212101639/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/covid-19-vaccination/vaccination-in-estonia

Recommendations are made to protect elderly people.   Where possible, home-based services provided for the elderly by the local government of residence should be preferred to placement in a nursing home.  Residents of nursing homes should not be transferred between different homes.  Before meeting a person at risk, make sure you are safe from infection and ensure safety when meeting them: wear a mask, keep your distance, and clean your hands and surfaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220212101851/https://www.kriis.ee/en/sickness-health-vaccinations/coronavirus-and-preventing-its-spread/prevention-coronavirus

All residents of Estonia from the age of 12 are recommended to get vaccinated for free against COVID-19. Vaccination is open for those over 5.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220212101639/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/covid-19-vaccination/vaccination-in-estonia

All residents of Estonia from the age of 12 are recommended to get vaccinated for free against COVID-19. Vaccination is open for those over 5.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220212101639/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/covid-19-vaccination/vaccination-in-estonia

All residents of Estonia from the age of 12 are recommended to get vaccinated for free against COVID-19. Vaccination is open for those over 5.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220212101639/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/covid-19-vaccination/vaccination-in-estonia

The Nationwide Telework recommendation has now been reintroduced in areas currently experiencing increased levels of community transmission.   The recommendation is for all employees in the public sector to work remotely as extensively as possible if their duties so allow. The Government also recommends that private employers adopt similar extensive remote work practices, recognising, however, that workplaces will determine how to combine in-office and remote work in a way that ensures health security.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216145328/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/10623/government-recommends-remote-work-in-areas-in-the-community-transmission-phase-until-further-notice

The requirements for entry into Finland include the following:   - a certificate of a full approved COVID-19 vaccination series, OR  - a certificate of having had the COVID-19 disease and one approved COVID-19 vaccine, OR  - an EU Digital COVID Certificate for a COVID-19 disease had less than six months ago, AND  - a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in Finland.    These requirements apply to those born in or before 2006. They however do not apply to citizens of Finland, those with permanent residence in Finland or persons travelling for essential reasons. Those who do not meet the requirement are required to have a mandatory covid test.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220106182331/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210820141655/https://koronavilkku.fi/en

No change in policy. The Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare recommends that masks are used in all public indoor spaces and on public transport, throughout the country. The recommendation applies to both vaccinated and unvaccinated persons. The Finnish Institute of Health and Welfare recommends a third dose of coronavirus vaccine for    - persons with severe immunodeficiency and aged 12 or over  - persons who have been vaccinated with a short interval of less than 6 weeks and are aged 18 or over  all persons aged 60 and over  - persons living in institutions and care homes and aged 18 or over  - persons in medical high-risk groups 1 and 2 and aged 18 or over health care personnel who treat coronavirus patients, personnel of 24-hour care facilities and other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220113120359/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/vaccines-and-coronavirus/getting-vaccinated-against-covid-19-how-why-and-when-

Current guidelines for protection of the elderly include:  - maintaining good hand hygiene  - Keeping a safe distance from other people  - Using a face mask when you are in places with many other people  - Social distancing  - Following the instructions of the contact tracing app.    A third coronavirus vaccine is also recommended for people over the age of 60. It was announced that baccalaureate specialty exams, scheduled for March 14 to 16, are postponed to May 11, 12 and 13 due to the Covid-19 epidemic.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20220115062509/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    Use of the "Vaccine Pass" is not required to access schools or educational facilities - https://web.archive.org/web/20220128182239/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

No change in policy, a Vaccine Pass is not required to access schools or other educational facilities (although any outing for a non-usual activity (e.g. school trip to the cinema), involving a mix with the public, requires the presentation of a "health pass" since September 30 for students aged 12 and two months and over (school, colleges, high schools) and in Universities, the "health pass" is not required to access courses, and can only apply to certain festive, cultural, sports and educational activities welcoming external participants or whose number is more than 50 people.) - https://web.archive.org/web/20220206173803/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220206173803/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221070953/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

On return from the Winter holidays (either 21 February, 28 February or 7 March, depending on the region of the country - https://web.archive.org/web/20220216093310/https://www.education.gouv.fr/calendrier-scolaire-100148) the health protocol applied to schools moves from Level 3 to Level 2.     Three main changes now apply:     - The end of the obligation to wear a mask outdoors for elementary school students and staff;  - The possibility of practicing physical and sports activities indoors again without wearing a mask (respecting a distance: contact sports are therefore not allowed without a mask);  - The lightening of the rules limiting social mixing (by level or group of classes rather than by class), especially during break times.    In addition, legal guardians of students who have been in contact with a confirmed Covid-19 case in their class will no longer be obliged to send a signed "Declaration of Honour" that their child has completed the proscribed regime of self-testing in order for them to return to school after isolation, and that testing regime will be relaxed to one self-test rather than two from 28 February.     There are no reported policy changes for colleges and Universities.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220221070953/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220225010222/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

Discotheques and nightclubs are currently closed, but will be allowed to re-open and standing concerts will be allowed from 16 February  - https://web.archive.org/web/20220128182452/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    All healthcare workers, and administrative and ancillary staff working for healthcare providers, home helps, are subject to mandatory vaccination - https://web.archive.org/web/20220128203947/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-vaccinal    Additionally, from 24 January the "Health Pass" has been replaced by the "Vaccine Pass" for all people aged 16 and over. A vaccination pass is required for all employees and customers/visitors to:     - places of entertainment and leisure (cinemas, museums, theatres, sports and entertainment venues, libraries, and others)  - bars and restaurants;  - long-distance/inter-regioanl transport by plane, train or bus  - fairs, professional seminars and exhibitions  - stores and shopping centres (depending on the decision of the prefect)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128203947/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-vaccinal

No change in policy - discotheques and nightclubs remain closed, but will be allowed to re-open on 16 February. Standing concerts are also prohibitied until that date.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220209213558/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    A Vaccine Pass is required for all employees and customers/visitors to:     - places of entertainment and leisure (cinemas, museums, theatres, sports and entertainment venues, libraries, and others)  - bars and restaurants;  - long-distance/inter-regioanl transport by plane, train or bus  - fairs, professional seminars and exhibitions  - stores and shopping centres (depending on the decision of the prefect)    the Vaccine Pass applies to all people aged 16 and over, and proves that the bearer has either completed a full vaccination schedule, has recovered from Covid-19 in the past 6 months, or has contraindications for vaccination. From 15 February, the rules relating to the Vaccination Pass are changing for people over 18 years and 1 month of age. The booster dose should be carried out as early as 3 months after the end of its initial vaccination schedule and within a maximum of 4 months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220210095345/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-vaccinal

From 24 January, the classification of countries on the 3-stage system of Green/Orange/Red has been adjusted with some countires and territories moving from Red or Green status to Orange. Countries of the travellers origin are categorised as follows:     "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Hong Kong, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay and Vanuatu. (previously, Argentina and Australia were on the Green list, but have moved to Orange)    "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories. Reinforced measures are in force for travel between France and the United Kingdom. The Travel Advice sheet for the United Kingdom should be consulted.    "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus with the presence of variants of concern is observed. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, the United States, Georgia, Mauritius, Montenegro, Nigeria, Pakistan, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Suriname, Tanzania, Turkey. (previously, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Moldova, Mozambique, Namibia, Russia, South Africa, Ukraine, Zambia and Zimbabwe were on the Red list, and have now moved to Orange)    All passengers from Red list countries must present negative results of a PCR or antigen test taken in the previous 48 hours at boarding and may be tested again on arrival. Unvaccinated passengers are subject to presentation of "compelling reasons" for travel, mandatory antigen testing on arrival, and must quarantine for 10 days under the control of security forces.     Passengers from Orange list countries must present negative results of a PCR or antigen test taken in the previous 48 hours at boarding. Vaccinated passengers are not subject to the "compelling reasons" regime, but unvaccinated people are and must commit to self-isolation lasting 7 days and undergo testing at the end of this period.     Although an Orange list country, additional regulations apply to all passengers aged 12 or over arriving from the United Kingdom from 14 January:     - All travelers, vaccinated or not, must present a negative test (PCR or antigen test) taken less than 24 hours before travel  - For vaccinated travellers, there is no longer any obligation to justify a compelling reason to come to France, nor an obligation to respect a period of isolation on arrival on the national territory. As such, the need to register, prior to travel, on the digital platform "eOS passenger" is lifted. Screenings on arrival may be conducted at the places of arrival. In the event of a positive result, the traveller will be placed in solitary confinement.  - For unvaccinated travellers, travel to or from the United Kingdom is permitted provided that it can prove compelling reasons valid for "red" countries.  - Unvaccinated travellers from the United Kingdom must continue to register, before their departure, on the eOS passenger digital platform, allowing them to enter the address of their stay in France. They must, upon arrival in France, observe a strict quarantine period of 10 days at this place; this quarantine will be controlled by law enforcement.    Specific guidance for UK passengers is available at https://web.archive.org/web/20220117202519/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/deplacements#voyager_dans_l'union_europeenne    Passengers from Green List countries are divided into two groups:     1. Member States of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See and Switzerland - Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a test (PCR or antigenic) of less than 24 hours. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    2. Bahrain, Hong Kong, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, The United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu:  All travelers twelve years of age or older, regardless of their vaccination status,from these countries/territories must present for boarding, the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) carried out less than 48 hours before the flight. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128204055/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220131221438/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/deplacements

From 4 February, the classification of countries from which travelers are subject to differentiated border controls based on health indicators is as follows:     - "Green" countries and territories: countries or territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Honduras, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay*, Vanuatu.  *Uruguay will move from the Green List to the Orange List as of February 6, 2022.  - "Orange" countries: countries in which there is an active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions, without diffusion of worrying variants. These are not all countries included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries.  - "Red" countries: countries in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. To date, there are no countries classified as "red".  - "Scarlet red" countries: countries in which a particularly active circulation of the virus and the discovery of a variant likely to present a risk of increased transmissibility or immune escape are observed. To date, there is no country classified as "scarlet red".    Anyone aged 12 and over entering French territory must present a negative PCR or antigen test of less than 24 hours or 48 hours depending on the country of origin. The only exception is that people with a complete vaccination schedule do not have to be tested when arriving from a Member State of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See or Switzerland.    Specific rules in place for travel to and from the UK were relaxed on 4 February from those implemented in January. As of this date, travelers from the UK are included in the provisions of travelers from the list of Orange countries, with the nuance that unvaccinated travelers from the UK must provide results of a PCR or antigen test taken within 24 hours of travel, and within 48 hours for vaccinated travelers.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20220205210857/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/deplacements     1/ travelers from a country/territory classified as "green"  1.1: for the Member States of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See and Switzerland:  Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a test (PCR or antigenic) of less than 24 hours. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    This obligation does not apply to the travel of road transport professionals in the exercise of their activity and to the following trips by land:    Journeys of less than 24 hours within a perimeter defined by a radius of 30 kilometres around the place of residence;  Business travel whose urgency or frequency is incompatible with the performance of a test or screening examination.  1.2: for Bahrain, Honduras, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, United Arab Emirates and Vanuatu:  All travellers twelve years of age or older, regardless of their vaccination status, from these countries/territories must present a negative PCR test or antigen test (GAD) taken less than 48 hours before the flight for boarding. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    2/ travellers from a country/territory classified as "orange": all countries/territories other than those mentioned in paragraph 1 ("green")    - All travellers twelve years of age or older, regardless of their vaccination status, must present a negative PCR test or antigen test (GAD) taken less than 48 hours before the flight. For unvaccinated travellers from the UK, the time to complete the PCR or antigenic test is 24 hours.    All travelers will be eligible for an antigen test upon arrival. In addition:    - vaccinated travellers (full vaccination schedule) are not subject to the regime of compelling reasons.  - unvaccinated travellers are subject to the imperative grounds regime and will have to commit to a 7-day self-isolation and undergo a test at the end of this period. The list of compelling reasons is specified in the travel and travel certificate issued by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France: the French, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their main residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20220205235349/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 6 February, Uruguay moves from the Green to the Orange list. There are no other policy changes. https://web.archive.org/web/20220211172530/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 12 February, the classification of countries from which travelers are subject to differentiated border controls based on health indicators is as follows:     - "Green" countries and territories: countries or territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Honduras, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan and Vanuatu.  - "Orange" countries: countries in which there is an active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions, without diffusion of worrying variants. These are not all countries included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries.  - "Red" countries: countries in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. Currently, there are no countries classified as "red".  - "Scarlet red" countries: countries in which a particularly active circulation of the virus and the discovery of a variant likely to present a risk of increased transmissibility or immune escape are observed. Currently, there is no country classified as "scarlet red".    In orer to enter France, travelers must comply with rules specific to their country of departure:     1: travelers from a country/territory classified as "green"  - Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a PCR test of less than 72 hours or antigenic test (TAG) of less than 48 hours.  - This obligation does not apply to the travel of road transport professionals in the exercise of their activity and to the following trips by land:  -- Journeys of less than 24 hours within a perimeter defined by a radius of 30 kilometres around the place of residence;  -- Business travel whose urgency or frequency is incompatible with the performance of a test or screening examination.    2: Travellers from a country/territory classified as "orange": all countries/territories other than those mentioned in paragraph 1 ("green")  Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a PCR test of less than 72 hours or antigenic test (TAG) of less than 48 hours. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    In addition:     - vaccinated travellers (full vaccination schedule) are not subject to the regime of compelling reasons.  - unvaccinated travellers are subject to the imperative grounds regime and will have to commit to a 7-day self-isolation and undergo a test at the end of this period. The list of compelling reasons is specified in the travel and travel certificate issued by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France: the French, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their main residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.    Whilst no countries are currently specified as Red or Scarlet Red, nnvaccinated travellers from these countries/territories would still be subject to the regime of compelling reasons for entering France, must present at boarding a negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) carried out less than 48 hours before the flight, will be subject to a mandatory antigen test upon arrival, and would be subject to a mandatory 10-day quarantine,controlled by the security forces.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20220213064422/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19     The specific rule requiring travelers from the United Kingdom to present results of a Covid-19 test taken within 24 hours of departure (rather than the usual 48 hours requires for travelers from other Orange list countries) has been rescinded as of 12 February. https://web.archive.org/web/20220213064422/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19 and https://web.archive.org/web/20220221213430/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/france/entry-requirements

From 16 February, the categorisation of Green / Orange list countries has been updated as follows:     "Green" countries/territories : countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Bahrain, Cape Verde, Cambodia, Colombia, South Korea, CÃ´te d'Ivoire, Cuba, The United Arab Emirates, Ecuador, Gabon, Ghana, Guinea, Equatorial Guinea, Guinea, Honduras, Hong Kong, Fiji, Mauritius, Samoa, Islands, Indonesia, Japan, Kuwait, Laos, Mauritania, Morocco, Nepal, Chad, New Zealand, Nicaragua, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Tanzania, Togo, Uganda, Vanuatu, Venezuela and Vietnam.    "Orange" countries/territories : countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" countries/territories.    There are currently no countries categorised as Red or Scarlet Red.     Entry regulations applicable to travelers from these countries are unchanged. https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071051/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

Policies relating to the allowances paid to employers whose employees are obliged to reduce the number of hours worked were updated for the period 28 January to 28 February 22, providing:     - 36% of the employee's previous gross salary within the limit of 4.5 SMIC with a floor of â¬7.53    - 70% of the employee's previous gross remuneration (i.e. approximately 84% of the net salary), within the limit of a remuneration of 4.5 SMIC, with a floor of â¬8.37 per hour, regardless of the company's workforce  -- in establishments open to the public and closed by administrative decision to combat the spread of the covid19 epidemic  --in establishments located in a reconfined territory when they suffer a 60% loss of turnover either in relation to the turnover recorded during the month preceding the implementation of the reconfinement, or in relation to the turnover recorded for the same month in 2019.  -- for employers belonging to so-called protected sectors (S1, S1 Bis) and which suffer a decrease in turnover of at least 65 % compared to the turnover recorded for the same month in 2020 or 2019, in respect of the turnover achieved over the previous six months compared to the same period in 2019, compared to the average monthly turnover achieved in 2019 or, for companies created after 30 June 2020, in relation to the average monthly turnover achieved between the date of creation of the company and 30 june 2021 (before 1er December 2021, this drop in turnover had to be at least 80%) or subject to health restrictions. These companies can benefit from the partial activity scheme without any remaining expenses. The derogation of partial activity without remaining at the expense of these employers is renewed.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20220211172553/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/dispositif-de-chomage-partiel    There are no changes to the policies supporting the self-employed - https://web.archive.org/web/20220211172612/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/reponses-gouvernement-difficultes-independants

PCR and antigen tests are widely available, per the US Embassy in France:     - Antigen test results are available within 24 hours, often in less than one hour. PCR test results may take up to 48 hours.   - Numerous pharmacies offer rapid antigen tests on a walk-in basis. To locate pharmacies open after-hours, weekends, or holidays in Paris and outskirts visit https://web.archive.org/web/20220206184330/https://monpharmacien-idf.fr/?. To find late-night or emergency pharmacies anywhere in France, call 112 (European emergency number, available free of charge, 24/7).  - PCR testing is available?at many?laboratories and testing centers, usually by appointment â including the testing centers at?Parisâ airports.   - Antigen tests cost 25 Euros, payable in advance.?PCR tests cost 43.89 Euros. As of October 15 [2021], free COVID tests?at public testing centers?for French residents?are no longer available, with an exception for fully vaccinated residents or residents with a prescription.?Private testing centers, including pharmacies, may charge. COVID test results can be obtained on paper, or via email or SMS message.?     - https://web.archive.org/web/20220205235318/https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Government policy is described at https://web.archive.org/web/20220205235520/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tests-et-depistage

Some relaxation in facial covering requirements, as from 21 February as schools return from Winter holidays (21 or 28 February, or 7 March depending on region) masks no longer need to be worn outdoors by elementary school students and staff. Face coverings are also no longer required for indoor school physical and sports activities where social distancing is possible (so, contact sports are therefore not allowed without a mask). https://web.archive.org/web/20220221070953/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    Face coverings are still required on public transport and in some enclosed public spaces such as stadiums, concert halls, and theaters - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071002/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Vaccination is universally available to people aged 5 and over.     From 24 January, vaccination boosters are available to all people aged 12 and over from three months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19. Prior to this date, booster vaccinations were available to everyone aged 18 and over.     People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220128204853/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Vaccination is universally available to people aged 5 and over, with one parent's permission required for children aged between 5 and 11.     Vaccination boosters are available to all people aged 12 and over from three months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     Vaccination is mandatory for all those who work in contact with frail people. Thus, since September 15, 2021, the following must be vaccinated:    - all staff (including administrative staff) of health institutions, medico-social institutions (EHPAD, USLD, autonomous residences, disability structures with or without accommodation and including non-medicalized), social institutions attached to a health institution (LHSS, LAM, CSAPA, CAARUD, CLAT, CEGGID);  - home helpers working with people affecting APA or PCH, in home services or as employees of individual employers;  - staff of medical transport companies (including taxis under agreement);  - all professions in Book IV of the CSP, whether or not under agreement, and professions for the use of titles, as well as their employees (e.g. medical secretaries, dental assistants);  - all health students;  - SDIS-Firefighters (professionals and volunteers);  - occupational health service personnel.  - Persons justifying a contraindication to vaccination are exempt from the vaccination obligation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206174049/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Up to 100 people may gather at events and assemblies, but exceptions may be allowed if venues meet the following conditions:  Standing: 4 square metres per person  Seated: 2 square metres per person  Example: A 500 square-metre venue can take 125 people (standing) or 250 people (seated).  Event organisers and others are advised to consult with the COVID-19 advisory group for further assistance.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220201193709/https://korona.fo/current-recommendations?_l=en

Maximum gatherings  A maximum of 100 people can gather in one place. If the circumstances allow it, more people can gather, provided that there is enough space:  Standing: at least 4 square meters per person  Sitting: at least 2 square meters per person  Example: in a 500 square meter room, 125 people can gather standing, or 250 people sitting.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220209040107/https://korona.fo/current-recommendations?_l=en

26 January- Nightclubs reopen in Northern Ireland, still legal requirement to present evidence of vaccination to enter in all nations, so 2G coding remains    https://archive.vn/uKOuw    From Wednesday, the legal requirement to provide proof of your Covid-19 status will only apply in relation to nightclubs and indoor unseated or partially seated events with 500 people or more in Northern Ireland      https://archive.vn/dNirZ

England's Plan B measures are to end from Thursday 27 January. Covid passports dropped meaning all businesses are open, without any requirement to present a pass to get in. Mandatory Covid passports for entering nightclubs and large events would end, though organisations could choose to use the NHS Covid pass if they wished. People would no longer be advised to work from home and should discuss their return to offices with employers  Face masks will no longer be mandated, though people are still advised to wear coverings in enclosed or crowded spaces and when meeting strangers.    Covid passes still required in other devolved nations for access to some businesses so coding remains at a 2, but now Targeted not General    http://web.archive.org/web/20220121121233/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-60047438

Covid passes remain in place in Scotland until 28 Feb http://web.archive.org/web/20220225175202/https://news.sky.com/story/covid-19-scotland-to-end-certification-scheme-next-monday-nicola-sturgeon-announces-12548758    Covid passes lifted elsewhere https://archive.vn/QGsHE

Changes to be introduced 11 February for fully vaccinated travellers    Mr Speaker, from 4am on the 11th February, and in time for the half-term break, eligible fully vaccinated passengers arriving in the UK will no longer have to take a post-arrival, lateral flow test.    Today I can announce that passengers who do not qualify as fully vaccinated will no longer be required to do a day 8 test after arrival or, indeed, to self-isolate. They will still need to fill out a passenger locator form to demonstrate proof of a negative COVID test taken 2 days before travel, and they must also take a post-arrival PCR test.      https://archive.vn/FNxIc

Rules for non-vaccinated changed on 11 February, meaning that non-vaccinated people do not need to quarantine upon arrival in the UK. Rules as follows:    Fully vaccinated â from 11 February  If you qualify as fully vaccinated for travel to England, you:    will not need to take a COVID-19 test before you travel to England or after you arrive  will not need to quarantine when you arrive  You will need to complete a passenger locator form before you travel to England.    Check if you can follow the rules for people who are fully vaccinated â includes people aged 17 and under.    Not fully vaccinated â from 11 February  If you do not qualify as fully vaccinated for travel to England, you will need to:    show proof of a negative COVID-19 test â test to be taken in the 2 days before you travel to England  book and pay for a COVID-19 PCR test â to be taken after you arrive in England  complete a passenger locator form before you travel to England  You will need to book the PCR test before you travel.    You will not need to quarantine, unless the result of the PCR test is positive.      http://web.archive.org/web/20220210131053/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-to-england-from-another-country-during-coronavirus-covid-19    http://web.archive.org/web/20220211134511/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-to-england-from-another-country-during-coronavirus-covid-19

24 February    Fully vaccinated: Before you travel to England you must complete a passenger locator form. You need to do this in the 48 hours before you arrive in England.    Not fully vaccinated: Must complete PCR test but from 24 February, there is no legal requirement to self-isolate if you get a positive day 2 test result.      http://web.archive.org/web/20220224030744/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-to-england-from-another-country-during-coronavirus-covid-19    http://web.archive.org/web/20220225155734/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-to-england-from-another-country-during-coronavirus-covid-19

Public and private schools in Georgia resumed in-person studies following winter holidays on January 17. Facemask use mandatory for all students.   https://archive.vn/GWEwD  https://archive.vn/VQDKH

Public institutions are instructed to move their staff onto the remote format of work to the maximum extent possible and a similar recommendation is given by the Council to employers in the private sector.  https://archive.vn/VQDKH

Any type of entertainment activities, arts and culture events (except for stage performances and cinema), festivals are going to be fully banned. The referred restriction does not apply to concerts to be held at the premises of hotels. As for sports tournaments of various types, they may be held without spectators. Nevertheless, every participant should be vaccinated (14 days should be lapsed from the second dose) or have a PCR test result obtained in the past 72 hours or a negative result of an antigen test obtained in the past 24 hours.  https://archive.vn/VQDKH

Cinema and theater attendances 50%. Green Passports will no longer be required to be checked in Georgia for admission to public venues from February 1, 2022. The ban on concerts and festivals is removed so long as applicable regulations are observed. Restriction remains valid on holding the wide-scale entertainment and such social events, such as wedding parties, banquets, jubilees of various types and similar. Eateries and ritual venues of miscellaneous types will be sanctioned with 10 000 GEL for hosting such events but will be sealed if found in breach of the regulation for the second time. Nightclubs banned.   https://archive.vn/VQDKH
Transport is operating and face masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, including taxis and public transportation.  https://archive.fo/KHpr1
There is no curfew in place.   https://archive.fo/KHpr1
No restriction on intercity travel.   https://archive.fo/KHpr1

Foreign citizens arriving by air may be unconditionally admitted to Georgia if they present a COVID-19 vaccine certificate confirming receipt of two full doses of the vaccine (or one dose in the case of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine).    The requirement to self-isolate is terminated for unvaccinated visitors who are citizens or residents of the United States (and several other listed countries) and meet the listed requirements.     Travelers arriving by land or sea must be citizens or residents of listed countries and travel must be directly from a listed country (including Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Turkey), including transit through third countries.        Vaccinated travelers must present BOTH proof of vaccination and a negative PCR test result conducted 72 hours or less before arrival in Georgia (see above for details).  No follow-up PCR test is required.     Unvaccinated travelers must comply with the same requirements for unvaccinated travelers who arrive by air .  https://archive.fo/KHpr1

Greece reintroduced measures aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus pandemic amid concern that rising cases will pile pressure on the nationâs health care system.    As much as 50% of all private and public-sector employees will have to work from home between Jan. 3 and Jan. 16, Health Minister Athanasios Plevris said Monday. The government also ordered restaurants, bars, cafes and night clubs to close at midnight.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161816/https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=ea7e0e9d-7230-11ec-a53d-5a7175777570&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAyMS0xMi0yNy9ncmVlY2UtcmVpbnN0YXRlcy13b3JrLWZyb20taG9tZS1tYW5kYXRlLW5pZ2h0LWxpZmUtY3VyYnM=

no policy change     Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210802101710/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

All those travelling to Greece (aged 5 or above) must show proof of a professionally administered negative rapid COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before arrival or proof of a professionally administered negative PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival.     The measure affects all arrivals, regardless of vaccination status or country of departure. The only exception is for arrivals who have spent less than 48 hours in a country prior to arriving in Greece.                                              Random antigen testing on arrival applies to every arrival to Greece, regardless of the certificate in their possession. If you are selected, please keep in mind that the screening is mandatory and in case of refusal, authorities reserve the right to refuse entry into the country.    If you are selected for a test and test positive, you will be subject to mandatory quarantine, for which you may be required by the Greek authorities to move to a designated quarantine facility.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161137/https://www.dfa.ie/travel/travel-advice/a-z-list-of-countries/greece/

Guidelines for primary schools, day care institutions and recreational activities:  -In the case of infection at schools and institutions etc., it will most often be other contacts that are of concern.  -Children, who are other contacts to an infected person (child or employee) in a day-care nursery etc., in school (including boarding schools and private schools) or in connection with recreational activities, must follow the recommendations for other contacts. Learn more in the section If you have been together with an infected person/been exposed to infection but are not a close contact.  -However, roommates at boarding schools etc., must follow the guidelines for close contacts.  *updated since 12Jan2022  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117002207/https://corona.nun.gl/en/at-the-workplace/guidelines-for-primary-schools-day-care-and-after-school-activities/

In Greenland, there is a requirement that people aged 15 and older must be fully vaccinated if they want access to premises to which the public has access. Previously, a negative PCR test also gave access to such premises, but that is no longer possible.  -You must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19  -You are only allowed access to the following places if you are fully vaccinated against COVID-19:  1) Restaurants, cafes, pubs, discos and similar establishments.  2) Cultural institutions, including culture centres, cinemas, museums, exhibition halls, etc.  3) Community centres and similar establishments.  4) Libraries.  5) Indoor sports facilities, including sports colleges and sports halls, swimming pools, gyms, football pitches, etc.  6) Hairdressers, massage parlours, beauty clinics and similar establishments.  When are you fully vaccinated?  -People who have completed a full vaccination programme, for example two doses of Pfizer or Moderna vaccine or one dose of Johnson&Johnson vaccine, are considered fully vaccinated. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.  -If you have previously been infected with COVID-19 and can present documentation of a positive PCR test result which is between 14 days and 12 weeks old, you are covered by the same rules as if you were fully vaccinated.  *updated on 26Jan2022  https://web.archive.org/web/20211228235327/https://corona.nun.gl/en/corona-passport-digital-eu-covid-certificate/vaccination-as-a-requirement-for-access/

Corona passport (digital EU COVID certificate)  -People in Greenland who have been vaccinated can get a corona passport.  -You can use a corona passport e.g. if you are travelling abroad and you need to document that you have been vaccinated against COVID-19. In some countries, you must show your corona passport or documentation of previous infection upon arrival.  https://archive.vn/lWkU1    Area restrictions  -There is no longer an inventory of cities and settlements with spread of infection from unknown sources. Restrictions regarding use of face masks and maximum occupancy of establishments apply to the entire country with exception of Ittoqqortoormiit and Tasiilaq, as well as the settlements Kulusuk, Isortoq, Kuummiut, Sermiligaaq and Tiniteqilaaq. The executive order is published on Naalakkersuisutâs announcement portal. Current restrictions are also explained in detail on the various pages at corona.nun.gl  https://archive.vn/Bp0OH    *updated guidelines and restrictions since 04 Feb 2022

Domestic travel in Greenland  Face masks:  It is not a requirement to wear a face mask on Air Greenland domestic flights in Greenland. However, the authorities recommend that all domestic travellers over the age of 12 wear a face mask or visor that covers both nose and mouth.  Last updated Wednesday 16. february  https://web.archive.org/web/20220215022115/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/domestic-travel/

Stay at home and isolate if you have COVID-19 symptoms or have tested positive.  If you have COVID-19 symptoms or are infected with the coronavirus you should isolate.  To isolate means:  -You must stay at home and not meet with other people who you do not live with.  -You must avoid contact with the people you live with.  -You must pay special attention to good hygiene and cleaning.  If you have tested positive for the coronavirus and it is not possible to keep to a sufficient distance from others in your household, the municipality may possibly provide you with voluntary isolation accommodation outside the home. For example, if your home is very small or you share your household with people who are at an increased risk of serious illness from COVID-19. Call the coronavirus hotline and learn about your options.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206130814/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/infection-prevention-advice/

The six pieces of advice are given in more detail below:  1. Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or a resident of Greenland or you are relocating to Greenland.    -In regard to entering Greenland, you are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -You must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test from a Nordic country (Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Iceland, Faroe Islands), UK, Liechtenstein, Switzerland, or a country in EU that is maximum 48 hours old from the time of departure and have valid documentation showing this.  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. This rule applies to everyone at 12 years old or older.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211220215011/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -From January 26 2022 and onwards, there is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or a resident of Greenland or you are relocating to Greenland.  -In regard to entering Greenland, you are considered fully vaccinated immediately after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -Documentation of your vaccine status  -Certificate of residence or something else that documents that you are a resident of Greenland (applies to unvaccinated citizens who are living in Greenland)  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. -This rule applies to everyone at 12 years old or older.  -Special rules apply if you have previously been infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 weeks. Read more in the section âPreviously infected with COVID-19â here.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129073108/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Conditions for entry into Greenland  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.    You are considered fully vaccinated immediately after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccine to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -If you are not a resident in Greenland, you must bring documentation that you are fully vaccinated or a positive PCR test result which, at the time of departure, is at least 14 days and at most 12 weeks old  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must bring a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must show a lease, employment contract or something else that documents your move  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. This rule applies to everyone at 12 years and older.  *updated policy  https://archive.vn/uwO8J

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.  -Special rules apply if you have previously been infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 weeks. Read more in the section âPreviously infected with COVID-19â here.  -You are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccine to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -If you are not a resident in Greenland, you must bring documentation that you are fully vaccinated.  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must bring a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must show a lease, employment contract or something else that documents your move  https://web.archive.org/web/20220201102406/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Test result:  -If your test is positive, it means you are infected with the coronavirus.  -If your COVID-19 test is positive, you will receive your test result via SMS. You are responsible for contacting your close contacts. Read more about the definition of a close contact.  -If you have taken an antigen test (home test) which shows a positive result, you should consider yourself infected with COVID-19. You must follow the same guidelines, but you will not be contacted by the healthcare system.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206141614/https://corona.nun.gl/en/infection-and-symptoms/if-you-test-positive/

If you test positive:  Test result  -If your test result is positive, it means you are infected with the coronavirus.  -If your result from a PCR-test is positive, you will receive your test result via SMS. You are responsible for contacting your close contacts. Read more about the definition of a close contact.  -If you have taken an antigen test (home test) which shows a positive result, you should consider yourself infected with COVID-19. You must follow the same guidelines, but you will not be contacted by the health department / corona secretariat.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220215024602/https://corona.nun.gl/en/infection-and-symptoms/if-you-test-positive/

Use of face masks and visors:  -Face masks can be used as a supplement for preventing the spread of infection in situations where it is difficult to keep to distance. It is important that you continue to follow the advice relating to keeping a distance and good hygiene even when you wear a face mask.    In Greenland, you must wear a face mask in the following situations:  -All individuals aged 12 years or older on domestic or international flights (face masks must be worn to the quarantine location/end destination).  -If you have been infected or risk of being infected with COVID-19 and in exceptional circumstances must move outside, e.g. because you need to get tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129080932/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/use-of-face-masks-and-visors/

The older you are â the more and more serious chronic diseases have â the more attention you need to pay to following the recommendations. You must naturally take your quality of life into consideration, when you place limits on your life.  *Risk Groups and Vulnerable People  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129081722/https://corona.nun.gl/en/information-about-covid-19/

Good advice for people at a higher risk:  -In general, if you are someone who is at a higher risk, you can continue to do the things you did before the COVID-19 pandemic, e.g. go to work, participate in leisure activities and take care of your grandchildren.  -If before the COVID-19 pandemic, you had to follow special precautions in your daily life to avoid being infected with an infectious disease, e.g. you have a special condition and are immunocompromised, you should continue to follow those precautions.    The National Board of Health in Greenland (âLandslÃ¦geembedetâ) recommends the following for persons who are at a higher risk:  -Get re-vaccinated  -Follow the recommendations from the Office of the Medical Director of Health and ask others to be mindful  -Avoid large events and gatherings of people where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider using a face mask in public spaces where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider talking with your workplace about how to ensure that you can go to work safely    The older you are â the more and more serious chronic diseases have â the more attention you need to pay to following the recommendations. You must naturally take your quality of life into consideration, when you place limits on your life.  *Risk groups and highly vulnerable people  https://web.archive.org/web/20220215030314/https://corona.nun.gl/en/information-about-covid-19/

No change in policy.  Self-testing on SARS-CoV-2 rapid antigen tests is voluntary and free and is performed once a week. Although it is recommended that students self-test on Mondays before school (or Sundays before bedtime), testing can be done on another day of the school-specific week, depending on when the first test is delivered to each school. It is important that the self-test is performed once a week and that the interval between the two tests is equal. For example, parents / guardians may record a negative test result in a student's notebook presented by the student at school or may report it in another way determined by the school.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220219124852/https://www.koronavirus.hr/upute-ravnateljima-o-primjeni-modela-ukidanja-samoizolacija-u-osnovnim-i-srednjim-skolama-uz-provodenje-redovitog-dobrovoljnog-samotestiranja-ucenika/1004

Jobs related to the health care system also have specially prescribed measures that employees must adhere to so that the system itself is not overloaded.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220206191121/https://www.koronavirus.hr/o-poslu/46

As of January 10, 2022, the Government of Croatia is imposing a range of epidemiological measures:    Indoor public gatherings are limited to 25 people.  Outdoor public gatherings are limited to no more than 50 people.  Outdoor public gatherings where everyone has EU digital certificates are limited to 200.  Private ceremonies will be limited to 20. Exception: private ceremonies in which everyone has a covid certificate will be limited to 50 people.  Sporting events and competitions: Indoor sports facilities may operate with up to 20 percent of spectator seating occupied. Outdoor events may operate with up to 40 percent of spectator seating occupied.  Catering / Dining establishments will be under more robust and compliance checks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129104715/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

negative PCR test result not older than 72 hours from the moment of testing, or rapid antigen test result - RAT for SARS-CoV-2 that is included in the Common list of rapid antigen tests recognized by the Member States of the European Union, published by the European Commission, provided that the test result is not older than 48 hours from the moment of testing to the moment of arrival at the border crossing point  certificate not older than 365 days of receipt of two doses of vaccine used in EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm) or vaccines approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use (Serum Institute of India - Covishield, Bharat Biotech - Covaxin, Sinovac - CoronaVac) or presentation of a certificate not older than 365 days of receipt one dose of vaccine received in one dose (Janssen / Johnson & Johnson) if 14 days have passed since receiving that one dose;  certificate showing that they have recovered from COVID-19 and have received one dose of vaccine used in EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm within eight months from contracting the disease, provided that the vaccine was administered less than 356 days from their arrival at the border crossing point;  a positive PCR or rapid antigen test result, referred to in paragraph III, item 1, subitem 1 of the said Decision, confirming that the holder recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection, which was performed in the previous 365 days, and which is older than 11 days from the date of arrival at the border crossing point, or a certificate of recovery from COVID-19 issued by a physician;  or they will be imposed self-isolation upon arriving in the Republic of Croatia with a possibility of getting a PCR test or rapid antigen test for SARS-CoV-2 and if they cannot get tested, they have to self-isolate for a total of 10 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129111606/https://mup.gov.hr/uzg-covid/english/286212

Quarantine Information:  Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? No  Travelers may be ordered to self-isolate or spend up to 14 days in official government quarantine facilities if deemed necessary to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Placement in quarantine is at the expense of the traveler.  Travelers who do not receive self-isolation orders are given a?Pamphlet with Recommendations and Instructions?from the Croatian Institute of Public Health that they must follow for 14 days after entering the country.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220214092352/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in policy.  The necessary epidemiological measure of self-isolation is automatically determined for all passengers in transit, including personnel in the transport sector, if they do not leave the Republic of Croatia within 12 hours from the moment of entering the Republic of Croatia.    Citizens of EU Member States (including Croatian citizens), i.e. Schengen Member States and Schengen associated countries, as well as members of their families and third-country nationals who are long-term residents under Council Directive 2003/109/EC of 25 November 2003 concerning the status of third-country nationals who are long-term residents and persons entitled to reside under other EU directives or national law or who have national long-term visas and are coming from third countries, must present a valid EU Digital COVID Certificate when entering the Republic of Croatia.    Exceptionally, the abovementioned category of passengers who do not yet possess an EU Digital COVID Certificate will be allowed entry into the Republic of Croatia if they have the following:     negative PCR test result or rapid antigen test result - RAT for SARS-CoV-2, where the RAT test must be listed in the Common list of rapid antigen tests recognized by the Member States of the European Union, published by the European Commission. If the RAT test results were made abroad, the manufacturer and/or the commercial name of the test must be visible. Otherwise, it will not be accepted as credible for entering the Republic of Croatia.  The PCR test result must not be older than 72 hours and the RAT test result must not be older than 24 hours, counting from the time the test was taken until the arrival at the border crossing point;   certificate that they have received two doses of vaccine used in the EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm, Novavax) or vaccines approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use (Serum Institute of India - Covishield, Bharat Biotech - Covaxin, Sinovac - CoronaVac) not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since receiving the second dose of the vaccine, or a certificate that they have received one dose of the vaccine if the vaccine is administered in a single dose (Janssen/Johnson&Johnson) not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since they received the single dose, or a certificate that they have received the booster dose of the vaccine;  certificate showing that they have recovered from COVID-19 and have received one dose of vaccine used in EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm, Novavax, Janssen/Johnson&Johnson) or a vaccine approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use (Serum Institute of India - Covishield, Bharat Biotech - Covaxin, Sinovac - CoronaVac), provided that 14 days have passed since they received the single dose within eight months from contracting the disease, provided that the vaccine was administered less than 270 days from their arrival at the border crossing point;  positive PCR test result or rapid antigen test result, confirming that the holder recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection, which was performed in the previous 180 days and which is older than 11 days from the date of arrival at the border crossing point, or  a medical certificate of recovery;  or if they perform PCR testing or rapid antigen testing - RAT for SARS-CoV-2 immediately upon their arrival in the Republic of Croatia (at their own expense), with the obligation to stay in self-isolation until they obtain a negative test result. In case they cannot get tested, they have to self-isolate for seven (7) days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220219130513/https://mup.gov.hr/uzg-covid/english/286212

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Croatia? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within one calendar day? Yes  A test can be arranged at the following locations:?COVID-19 Testing Locations in Croatia.  The cost of a local test (rapid antigen test or a PCR test) ranges from $40 to $150 or more, depending upon the location, and the result can be expected between 1-48 hours depending upon the type of the test.  Effective December 6, 2021, all airline passengers to the United States ages two years and older must provide a negative COVID-19 viral test taken within one calendar day of travel. Alternatively, travelers to the U.S. may provide documentation from a licensed health care provider of having recovered from COVID-19 in the 90 days preceding travel.? Check the CDC website for additional information and?Frequently Asked Questions.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page:? https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/international-travel/before-you-go/covid-19_testing_required_US_Entry.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129104715/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
https://web.archive.org/web/20220129104715/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

PfizerâBioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.  According to the Croatian Institute for Public Health, foreigners with temporary or permanent residency in Croatia can register for the COVID-19 vaccine through their local healthcare provider.  If you have an OIB (Croatian Personal Identification Number) and a local health insurance plan, you may visit https://cijepise.zdravlje.hr/ to register to get vaccinated.  If you do not have a local health insurance plan, you may visit the following Croatian Institute of Public Health website for the contact details of the county public health institutes to register by phone.  Visit the FDAâs website to?learn more about FDA-approved vaccines?in the United States.  The United States Government does not plan to provide COVID-19 vaccinations to private U.S. citizens overseas. Please follow host country developments and guidelines for COVID-19 vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129104715/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Mask-wearing. From November 20, masks must be worn again in shops, shopping malls, post offices, customer services, theatres, cinemas, in museums and sporting events. At indoor cultural and other events, gyms, swimming pools, spas, and catering shops, employees must wear a mask.   Hospitals have been banned from visiting.  Source: https://archive.vn/jJwx3   The 'EU Digital COVID Certificate' (EUDCC) is required to access some public spaces, such as bars and restaurants, museums, large events, and some means of public transport.   Source: https://archive.vn/XxhwO  Note: Employers may require the vaccine to be taken. For unvaccinated workers, the employer may set a 45-day deadline for taking the first vaccination. Employers who expect to be vaccinated must inform the employee by e-mail or on paper about the measure, the deadline and the possible legal consequences of not taking the vaccine. Vaccination is not expected to be given to a worker who is vaccinated and is contraindicated.   Vaccination is expected in the public sector, and mayors can decide on it.  Confirmatory third vaccination is also required for health care and some public administration workers.   Source: https://archive.vn/jJwx3

Non-essential travel to Hungary is only allowed to Hungarian citizens who hold an immunity card; non-Hungarian nationals who provide proof of vaccination; non-vaccinated - recovery from COVID-19 or a negative test result.    For vaccinated: required to be vaccinated to enter.  For non-vaccinated: Hungarian citizens without vaccination certificates, returning from abroad, are obliged to stay in home quarantine for 10 days from the date of entry. Passengers returning home may be exempted from quarantine if they provide a certificate containing the negative results of two SARS-CoV-2 molecular tests performed in Hungary at two different times, with at least 48 hours between them.     Source: https://archive.vn/XxhwO

Non-essential travel to Hungary is only allowed to Hungarian citizens who hold an immunity card; non-Hungarian nationals who provide proof of vaccination; non-vaccinated - recovery from COVID-19 or a negative test result.    For vaccinated: required to be vaccinated to enter.  For non-vaccinated: Hungarian citizens without vaccination certificates, returning from abroad, are obliged to stay in home quarantine for 10 days from the date of entry. Passengers returning home may be exempted from quarantine if they provide a certificate containing the negative results of two SARS-CoV-2 molecular tests performed in Hungary at two different times, with at least 48 hours between them.     Source: https://archive.vn/XxhwO

No changes.  The government is providing several significant subsidies.  Parents receive a family tax refund. In February 2022, parents raising a child will be refunded their income tax paid in 2021 up to the tax level of the average wage.  Retirees received a larger-than-ever pension premium  of HUF 80,000 in November and will receive a full refund of their 13-month pension in February 2022.  Wage increases will continue: from January 2022, the minimum wage will be HUF 200,000 and the guaranteed minimum wage will be HUF 260,000,  thus the minimum wage will be higher from 2022 onwards.  Young people under the age of  25 will not have to pay income tax  from January 2022.  The credit moratorium was extended until June 30, 2022. Those who are expecting and raising a child, retirees, and those in public employment can continue to take advantage of the opportunity, as can businesses and individuals whose incomes have fallen significantly from the previous year.    Source: https://archive.vn/jJwx3
