Remaining restrictions  The following restrictions remain in place until 28 February 2022:    - Requirement of a vaccination or recovery certificate for international travel  - Use of face coverings to continue where currently required (for example, in shops and on public transport)  - Requirement to self-isolate if you have symptoms of COVID-19 and close contact guidance to remain in place  - Protective measures in primary and secondary schools and early year settings to remain in place    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211203513/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

On 21 January 2022, the Government announced a plan for easing COVID-19 restrictions.    From 6am on 22 January 2022:    - Pubs and restaurants can return to normal opening times (no longer must close at 8pm)  - Nightclubs can reopen  - You no longer need a vaccination or recovery certificate to access hospitality or indoor activites  - Social distancing is no longer required in hospitality or other settings  - Restrictions on numbers attending indoor and outdoor events or activities no longer apply  - Limits on household visits no longer apply    https://web.archive.org/web/20220103083837/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

Remaining restrictions  The following restrictions remain in place until 28 February 2022:    - Requirement of a vaccination or recovery certificate for international travel  - Use of face coverings to continue where currently required (for example, in shops and on public transport)  - Requirement to self-isolate if you have symptoms of COVID-19 and close contact guidance to remain in place  - Protective measures in primary and secondary schools and early year settings to remain in place    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211203513/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

You must complete a Passenger Locator Form online before you arrive in Ireland and tell the authorities if your residence details change within 14 days. This is set out in the SI 45 of 2021 (pdf), as amended, which applies until 6 February 2022. Failure to do this is an offence.    Some arrivals to Ireland are required to show proof of RT-PCR pre-departure testing.    Exemptions from pre-departure testing are set out in Statutory Instrument 135 of 2021 (pdf), as amended, which apply until 9 February 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128230204/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/health/covid19/public_health_measures_for_covid19.html

Following a recommendation of the European Union Commission, Ireland has announced that from February 1, travellers vaccinated with Novavax can enter the country under the same travel rules as those vaccinated with Pfizer, Moderna, Janssen, and AstraZeneca, as the vaccine has recently been approved for use in the EU  by the European Medicines Agency (EMA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220202162132/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/new-travel-rules-enter-into-force-today-in-ireland/

Remaining restrictions  The following restrictions remain in place until 28 February 2022:    - Requirement of a vaccination or recovery certificate for international travel  - Use of face coverings to continue where currently required (for example, in shops and on public transport)  - Requirement to self-isolate if you have symptoms of COVID-19 and close contact guidance to remain in place  - Protective measures in primary and secondary schools and early year settings to remain in place    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211203513/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

Since 1 February 2022, a standard acceptance period of 14 days after the final dose in a primary vaccine series of a vaccine will be required for all vaccines accepted for travel to Ireland.    You are fully vaccinated when it is:    14 days after the second AstraZeneca dose or second Covishield dose  14 days after the second Pfizer-BioNtech dose  14 days after the second Moderna dose  14 days after the single Janssen dose  14 days after the second Sinopharm dose (also called Vero Cell Inactivated)  14 days after your second dose of Coronavac (Sinovac)  14 days after your second dose of Covaxin  14 days after your second dose of of Novavax (Nuvaxovid)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222092310/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/travel_and_recreation/travel_to_ireland/travel_to_ireland_during_covid.htmla

Mask wearing IS still required in the following settings:    Situations where you are still required to wear a mask    public transport, taxis and at stations/airports/ports  retail premises (including shopping centres, libraries, cinemas, theatres, museums, post offices, banks), public offices and at premises providing specified services and businesses (incl. salons, hairdressers, travel agents, laundries, dry cleaners, bookmakers)  customer facing roles in premises where food and beverages are sold for consumption on the premises    https://archive.vn/VSLlU    http://web.archive.org/web/20220128230204/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/health/covid19/public_health_measures_for_covid19.html

Remaining restrictions  The following restrictions remain in place until 28 February 2022:    - Requirement of a vaccination or recovery certificate for international travel  - Use of face coverings to continue where currently required (for example, in shops and on public transport)  - Requirement to self-isolate if you have symptoms of COVID-19 and close contact guidance to remain in place  - Protective measures in primary and secondary schools and early year settings to remain in place    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211203513/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

By law, you must wear a face covering when using public transport. This includes in taxis, as well as in bus and rail stations.    Mask wearing will still be required in the following settings:    public transport, taxis and at stations/airports/ports  retail premises (including shopping centres, libraries, cinemas, theatres, museums, post offices, banks, credit unions), public offices and at premises providing specified services and businesses (incl. salons, hairdressers, travel agents, laundries, dry cleaners, bookmakers)  workers in customer facing and food preparation roles in premises where food and beverages are sold for consumption on the premises  healthcare settings    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222092940/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/0fc0d-government-announces-that-most-of-the-public-health-measures-currently-in-place-can-be-removed/?referrer=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gov.ie%2Fen%2Fpublication%2F3361b-public-health-updates%2F      From 28 February 2022, it is no longer mandatory to wear a face covering on public transport, in taxis, shops, schools and other indoor public areas. Staff in hospitality settings will no longer need to wear a face covering. . You are still recommended to wear a face mask in hospitals and health settings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222091958/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/health/covid19/face_coverings_during_covid19.html

31/01/22    No changes found, the rules/regulations applies to everyone, there is no indications as to whether different for vaccinated and non-vaccinated.    Current restrictions on school activities  The regulation issued by the Minister of Health on the restriction of school activities due to stricter infection prevention measures is effective until 24 February 2022.    Preschools and day-care parents  Maximum number of employees in each area: 50.  Minimum distance between employees: 1 meters.  Use of masks by employees: Where a 1-meter distance limit between employees is not possible. There is no mask obligation in communication with preschool children.  Transfer of employees between groups: Allowed.  Maximum number of children in each area: 50.  Minimum distance between children: None.  Use of face masks by children: None.  Outside area: no limits to the number of people.    Events related to the work or social activities of preschools, such as plays and concerts are allowed.      Primary schools and after-school activities  Grades 1 to 10    Maximum number of employees in an area: 50.  Minimum distance between employees: 1 meters.  Use of masks by employees: Where a 1-meter distance limit between employees and towards students is not possible.  Transfer of employees and students between groups: Allowed.  Maximum number of children in each area: 50.  Minimum distance between children: 1 meter in classrooms.  Use of face masks by children: None.  Physical education and school swimming lessons: Allowed.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.  Outdoor area: No restrictions, but efforts should be made to limit the number of students in each outdoor area unless it impedes outdoor activities.    The restrictions on the number of people do not apply on the school bus.    Events related to the work or social activities of primary schools, such as lectures, reading competitions, etc., are subject to the provisions on performing arts in the regulation on the restrictions on gatherings due to a pandemic.    After-school activities  The same restrictions apply as to preschools and primary schools. One individual is allowed to accompany a child of a preschool age in after-school activities.    Events related to the work or social activities of primary schools, such as plays and concerts, lectures, reading competitions, etc., are subject to the provisions on performing arts in the regulation on the restrictions on gatherings due to a pandemic.    Mixing between groups: Allowed.    Music schools  All music lessons for children at a preschool and primary school age is permitted with the same restrictions as apply to their school activities.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 50.  Minimum distance between individuals: 1 meters.  Use of face masks: Students born in 2005 and earlier, as well as employees, should wear masks if social distancing rules cannot be followed, if possible.  Transfer of employees between areas: Allowed.  Maximum number of students in an area: 50.  Studentsâ social distancing rules: Follow the rules for each school level.    Events related to the work or social activities of music schools, such as concerts, are subject to the provisions on performing arts in the regulation on the restrictions on gatherings due to a pandemic.    Upper secondary schools  Maximum number of employees and students in an area: 50.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 50.  Minimum distance between individuals: 1 meters.  Use of face masks: Where a 1 meter distance is not possible.  In classrooms, it is permitted to have a distance of 1 meter between students, but then the use of a face mask is required.  Transfer of employees and students between groups: Allowed.  Physical education: Allowed with the same restrictions as other teaching measures.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.    In situations where it is not possible to enforce social distancing, such as in practical teaching, art teaching and teaching students in vocational training, students and teachers must wear a face mask.    Students may stay in a dormitory.    Events related to work or social activities in upper secondary school are subject to the provisions on performing arts in the regulation on the restrictions on gatherings due to a pandemic.    Universities  Maximum number of employees and students per room: 50.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 50.  Minimum distance between individuals: 1 meters.  Use of face masks: Where a 1 meter distance is not possible.  In classrooms, it is permitted to have a distance of 1 meter between students, but then the use of a mask is required.  Transfer between groups: Allowed.  Physical education: Allowed with the same restrictions as other teaching measures.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.    In situations where it is not possible to enforce social distancing, such as in practical teaching, art teaching and clinical studies, school work is permitted as long as infection prevention measures are followed and on the condition that students and teachers wear a face mask.    This provision does not prevent students from staying in dormitories.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123191320/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

21/2/22    Schools  Rules on restrictions on gatherings apply to schools in all school stages with a few exceptions.  Social events at schools and upper secondary schools are allowed without any restrictions.  Shared areas (cafeteria, entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees and students born in 2005 and earlier, use face masks.    Mixing between groups is allowed in all school stages and employees are allowed to go between areas.  Social distancing rules do not apply in classrooms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221212536/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

21/2/22    Labour market  ?Managers are responsible for informing their employees of the workplaceâs response plan and what rules apply to its operation while the COVID-19 precautionary measures remain in effect. The need for meetings must be assessed, particularly if there are many attendees. Such meetings should preferably be held using teleconferencing equipment whenever possible. This also applies to meetings within the company if possible. Care must be taken as regards employee travel overseas. Then ecessity of travel must be assessed each time, and employees should avoid such travel unless it is unavoidable.    It is important that managers encourage their employees to take care of their health and to stay at home if they experience any illness. Employees with underlying illnesses are particularly at risk from the virus and should, therefore, consult with their superior as to the possibility of working from home as much as possible if that is an option.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221213153/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/workplaces

31/01/22    The rules/regulations applies to everyone, there is no indications as to whether different for vaccinated and non-vaccinated.  However, there is a change in the number:  Up to 500 people may attend certain events (performing arts, theater, cinema and funerals) if the following criteria is met:    1) All guests are seated and not facing each other  2) 1 meter social distancing between guests  3) All attendees wear a mask.  4) Alcoholic beverages are not sold before, during or after event.  5) Guests are asked to remain seated even if an interval is necessary, if at all possible.  Social distancing rules  At all workplaces and when performing other professional activities, individuals who are unrelated must keep a distance of 1 meter from each other.    At gatherings where all guests are seated 1 meter must be kept between guests, and a face mask must be worn.    Children born in 2016 and later are exempt from social distancing rules    https://web.archive.org/web/20220131004942/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

31/01/22    There is no clear indication that those unvaccinated are not allowed to travel to Iceland, however, those who are vaccinated are exempted from certain travel requirement which makes traveling easier.  People living in Iceland are strongly advised against unnecessary travel to risk areas due to COVID-19, except being fully vaccinated. Special rules apply when travelling to Iceland. Here you can read more regarding travel restrictions to Iceland as a result of COVID-19.    "This quick guide to COVID-19 border measures will help you find out what general rules apply when entering Iceland. The information provided here is for guidance only. A final decision on entry is in all cases made at the border.  Rules at the border  With vaccination certificate or a certificate of previous infection  Travellers without a vaccination certificate or a certificate of previous infection  Transit passengers"    source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220131012319/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/travel-to-and-within-iceland    People that have been infected with COVID-19 or have been vaccinated  Travel restrictions do not apply to foreign citizens who can provide appropriate proof of vaccination against COVID-19 or a prior COVID-19 infection that fulfills requirements set forth by the Chief Epidemiologist  Rules at the border are in force until February 28th 2022.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131012003/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/vaccination-and-antibodies    Arriving without a certificate of vaccination or a certificate that they have had COVID-19  Travel restrictions do not apply to other EEA/EFTA-citizens and citizens of Monaco, San Marino, and the Vatican.  Third-country citizens are still not authorized to travel to Iceland unless exemptions apply. Note: As of January 1, 2021, UK nationals have the status of third-country nationals.  Rules at the border are in force until February 28th 2022.  source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131012137/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/risk-areas    Other sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131011614/https://www.logreglan.is/english/regarding-travel-restrictions-to-iceland-as-a-result-of-covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220131011510/https://www.landlaeknir.is/um-embaettid/greinar/grein/item44162/Certificate-of-vaccination-against-COVID-19-accepted-at-the-border

21/2/22    People that have been infected with COVID-19 or have been vaccinated  Travel restrictions do not apply to foreign citizens who can provide appropriate proof of vaccination against COVID-19 or a prior COVID-19 infection that fulfills requirements set forth by the Chief Epidemiologist    Rules at the border are in force until February 28th 2022.    Rules at the border for people with vaccination or former COVID-19 infection  All travellers must pre-register before arriving in Iceland and confirm their departure day, if available.  Present a certficate of full vaccination, or a certificate of previous infection, at the border.  If a certificate is not valid the individual needs to undergo 2 tests and quarantine for 5 days in between.  NOTE. From 1 February 2022, a vaccination certificate is valid if no more than 270 days (9 months) have elapsed from the primary vaccination when an individual has not undergone a booster vaccination. Primary vaccination is considered complete after two doses of vaccine or after one Janssen injection. A booster dose cancels this expiration date.  Those who live in Iceland, or who have a network here, must go for COVID-19 testing within 48 hours of arriving in Iceland. They do not have to present a negative COVID-19 test at the border. Testing can be obtained at the border in KeflavÃ­k or at the health care centres all over Iceland. There is no need to quarantine while waiting for the results of this test, but travellers are asked to attend to personal infection control, limit contact with vulnerable individuals and be alert to the symptoms of COVID-19.  Rules for travellers without a network in Iceland: Vaccinated passengers, and those with prior infection of COVID-19, need to present a negative covid-19 test either a PCR or Rapid antigen test. NB. self-tests are not accepted. The test must have been taken within 72 hours before departure on the first leg of the journey. A fine for not presenting a negative COVID-19 test at the border is 100.000 ISK.  If a traveller has recently been diagnosed with COVID-19, they do not need to present a negative PCR or rapid antigen test at the border. Instead, a positive PCR test must be presented that is older than 7 days (isolation completed) but younger than 180 days. These individuals do not have to take a rapid antigen test or PCR test within 48 hours due to their connection with the country.  Testing and quarantine of children: Children under the age of 18 are permitted to travel to Iceland with their parents, given the parents are exempt from travel restrictions to Iceland. However, children born in or before 2004 need to undergo testing at the border, quarantine for 5 days and then be tested a second time, unless they have a certificate of full vaccination. Children born in 2005 or later are exempt from the rules at the border.  It is recommended that travellers download the Rakning C-19 app. It is used, amongst other things, to communicate negative test results and helps to trace infections if necessary.  If the slightest suspicion arises that an individual has presented a forged certificate, he/she/they will be obliged to be tested twice with quarantine in between.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221215242/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/vaccination-and-antibodies

21/2/22    Face masks  Face masks must be worn wherever the 1 meter social distancing rule cannot be observed between people who are unrelated.    Mask obligation does not apply to children born 2006 or later.    Face masks must be used where it is not possible to ensure 1 meter of social distancing, such as in healthcare services, museums, domestic flights and ferries, public transport, taxis and coaches, in practical driving lessons and flight training, hairdressers, beauty salons, massage parlours, tattoo parlours, dog grooming salons, tanning salons and other similar activities. Face mask needs to cover both nose and mouth.    Those who do not have the understanding or maturity to use a face mask correctly or are unable to do so for other reasons, such as health reasons, do not have to wear a mask.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221212536/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

no changes in policy, green passes are still required only for university students, so for those students that are non-vaccinated, there is a requirement to show a negative-test or a certification that they recently recovered from Covid. So for such university students some levels (university) are otherwise closed.  For vaccinated students masks and social distancing (desks are kept 1m apart) are still required.    Starting September 1st green passes are required for School Personnel only. All students are exempted from this requirement for the time being until and including high school. University students though need to have green passes in order to access the facilities of their university. Universities hence are virtually closed for students without a green pass.    Starting Dec 6th a vaccine mandate is in place for all school personnel.   University students still need to hold a green pass to attend lessons in presence.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220113115732/https://www.ilgiorno.it/cronaca/covid-obbligo-vaccini-lavoro-scuola-green-pass-1.7240336  http://web.archive.org/web/20211210170128/https://www.wired.it/article/green-pass-scuola-universita-regole-vaccino-mezzi/

Several regions are now orange zones and several local orange zones have been established in Sicily, in such zones curfews are in place except for the vaccinated and recently recovered from Covid (Super Green Pass).  Social distancing and masks are mandatory almost anywhere for everyone, including the vaccinated.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220128174715/https://www.ilgiorno.it/cronaca/super-green-pass-zone-1.7077178  https://web.archive.org/web/20220128173715/https://www.qualitytravel.it/colori-regioni-covid-19-le-nuove-zone-rosse-arancioni-gialle-e-bianche-dal-22-marzo/92843    Regions that are classified as Yellow zones are increasing in number. In Yellow zones no curfews are in place.  Some Italian regions are still classified as white zones.  A new summary table has been created to clearly explain which activities are possible in every zone with or without a Green Pass (negative test, vaccinated or fully recovered) or a Super Green Pass (only vaccinated or fully recovered from Covid):   https://web.archive.org/web/20220128174938/https://www.governo.it/sites/governo.it/files/documenti/documenti/Notizie-allegati/tabella_attivita_consentite.pdf

travel restrictions have ceased for South Africa.  For most countries it is mandatory to exhibit a negative test (antigen or PCR) in conjunction with a Super Green Pass (vaccinated or recovered) if this is not done people will have to self-quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220121174357/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto

For most countries, except for European countries, it is mandatory to exhibit a negative test (antigen or PCR) in conjunction with a Super Green Pass (vaccinated or recovered), if this is not done people will only be admitted if they have residency or working permits, and will therefore have to self-quarantine. For tourism and without a proof of vaccination, it won't be possible to enter Italy from countries in the D & E list.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220204150250/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto&tab=5

Quote: "Is public transportation operating? Yes  Bishkek city public transport operates on weekdays and weekends from 7:00 â 23:00.  Masks are required on public transit."    Archive link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220217132813/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

If your PCR test expires en route due to flight delays or cancellations, you will be required to test again upon arrival at your own expense." Quote: "Travelers must provide a negative PCR test.  PCR tests must be taken no more than 72 hours before arrival into Kyrgyzstan.  If your PCR test expires en route due to flight delays or cancellations, you will be required to test again upon arrival at your own expense.  As of February 11, 2021, travelers may show their original vaccine card showing proof of  As of February 11, 2021, travelers may show their original vaccine card showing proof of vaccination against COVID-19 instead of a negative PCR test.  Travelers without vaccination or valid PCR results will be denied entry.  Children under age 5 are exempt from testing or vaccination entry requirements." Quote: "24-hour COVID testing is available at Manas International Airport. Other local labs may have extended operating hours but do not provide 24-hour service. Travelers should plan accordingly to ensure that they will have current test results prior to boarding their flight(s).  The Ministry of Health provides free testing only for symptomatic patients. For those requiring a negative PCR test for travel, state laboratories in Bishkek and Osh can provide tests for a fee (approximately $20), depending on testing capacity. Private COVID-19 testing is also available for a fee ($30) at Bonetsky Laboratory or Aqualab. "  Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220217132813/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Schools are open but masks must be worn indoors. Contact service will be provided in schools. Schools are open but masks must be worn indoors. Schools are required to comply to the flow management, and other hygiene requirements.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220220214203/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

People without a vaccination cannot access non-essential stores, unless they can proof covid-recovery or provide a negative test.   Masks must be worn indoors.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220202113225/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

Work from home recommended. Medical face masks or respirators are a must in serving customers, in common areas and workplaces if there is more than one person in the room.  Flow management.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220214203/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

For those vaccinated, they must fill an arrival form, and a PCR or antigen test is recommended on the 3rd day of arrival at the latest. For those vaccinated, they must fill an arrival form and testing could be exempted. There are no restrictions on gatherings or events that take place in your private home. The CovidCheck disappears in private homes. The thresholds for gatherings are hereby amended as follows.  For gatherings  of up to 10 people, there are no restrictions or health measures to be observed  Gatherings of between 11 and 50 people (inclusive): if the gathering is not organised under the CovidCheck system, the double condition of wearing a mask and a minimum distance of 2 metres is compulsory  Gatherings of between 51 and 200 people (inclusive): if the gathering is not organised under the CovidCheck system, the triple condition of wearing a mask, being seated and keeping a minimum distance of 2 metres is compulsory  Gatherings of between 201 and 2,000 people are in principle subject to the CovidCheck system, if not to the triple condition of wearing a mask, being designated a seat and keeping a minimum distance of 2 metres  Over 2,000 people, gatherings are authorised provided they are subject to a health protocol to be accepted in advance by the Health Directorate  The provisions regarding sports and cultural activities have been adapted to reflect the reintroduction of the 3G system. This system applies as soon as the number of people in the group exceeds 10.  https://archive.ph/Dskgx
3G system applies to public events and leisure activities. https://archive.ph/7kR0i https://archive.ph/qpvg8

For gatherings of up to 10 people, there are no restrictions or health measures to be observed.  For gatherings of 11 to 20 people (inclusive), masks and a physical distance of 2 metres between people are mandatory, or the CovidCheck (2G+) system applies.   Gatherings of between 21 and 200 people (inclusive) are subject to the CovidCheck 2G+ system, or the requirement to wear a mask and be seated at a minimum distance of 2 metres. CovidCheck 2G+ means that each person over 12 years and 2 months of age must present a vaccination or recovery certificate. They must also undergo a test exempt vaccination within the last 180 days, booster vaccination or recovery certificate.   Gatherings of more than 200 people are prohibited, unless they are subject to a health protocol accepted in advance by the Health Directorate, which determines the health measures to be observed.   https://archive.ph/lgq7X
https://archive.ph/qRryU https://archive.ph/lgq7X

Certain goods and services in person are only available for vaccinated people with Covid-19 certificate. Non vaccinated people are able to acquire only essential products in shops.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220201124608/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures    - The following points of sale are available on the premises for non-vaccinated people (with a separate entrance from the outside and an area available to visitors not exceeding 1500 m2):         - grocery stores (with food, hygiene products, animal feed, press being 70% of the assortment);        - pharmacies (including veterinary);        - medical product stores (with medical products being 90% of the assortment);        - opticians;        - pet food stores;        - press outlets;         - hygiene goods stores (with hygiene items being 70% of the assortment);        - fuel stations;        - registered ticket offices at bus and train stations.    - A vaccinated/recovered person may provide to the unvaccinated/non-recovered client:     - services on-site if they cannot be provided remotely and, if the service is not provided ,it endangers ensuring of the fundamental human rights or maintaining public security;     - help in psychological support groups;     - public transport and international transport services, including international passenger services, and related services;     - commercial transport by taxi and car;     - postal services;     - takeaway and food delivery,;     - financial and insurance services (banking, consumer lending, insurance, currency exchange);      - emergency response and emergency utilities;      - repair and maintenance service;      -  telecommunications services (including telecommunications goods purchased together with the service);      -  veterinary services.

No entry bans from any country. The following rules applied to over 50 countries until January 17th and applies to all countries since then: Moldova requires anyone entering the country present one of the following:  1) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose); 2) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; or 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date.  Any COVID-19 antibodies certificate or evidence of vaccination must be in Romanian, English, French, German, Italian, or Russian language.  Moldovan Border Police accept all types of vaccination with appropriate documentation.  Absent one of the documents listed above, a traveler will have to self-isolate for 14 days.  Self-isolation may be discontinued after 7 days if a COVID-19 PCR test or a rapid SARS-CoV-2 Ag test is performed, and the result is negative based on a confirmative document.  If you are subject to self-isolation and depart Moldova, you could be fined for violating self-isolation.  Anyone required to self-isolate should complete an online epidemiological card 3 days before arriving in Moldova.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125001334/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

No changes. Moldova requires anyone entering the country present one of the following:  1) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose); 2) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; or 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214230300/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Those with one of the following documents can enter Moldova without having to self-isolate.  - proof that you have received both doses of an approved vaccination, with second dose administered at least 14 days before arrival  - negative result of a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before time of arrival  - negative result of a rapid antigen test taken no more than 48 hours hours before time of arrival  - a confirmation of the presence of COVID-19 antibodies (serological test) that is valid for a period of 90 days from the date of the test  All those without this documentation must complete an online epidemiological form and self-isolate for 14 days. Self-isolation can stop after 7 days with a negative PCR or antigen test.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220219193312/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/moldova/coronavirus

No changes in policy.  Key Policy Responses as of July 1, 2021. A comprehensive fiscal package has been adopted as per two 2020 State Budget Amendments, following several targeted fiscal measures to support businesses and vulnerable households, such as expanding unemployment benefits and strengthening existing targeted social assistance, tax relief for sectors affected by state-imposed restrictions, delaying tax payment deadlines to mid-2020, suspending tax audits and other controls, and increasing state budget allocations to the budget emergency and health funds and to a mortgage guarantee program. The approved 2021 Budget envisages more support to the health sector, and farmers support.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220130032441/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No change. COVID-19 testing is available at both public and private medical laboratories. People who do not have Moldovan health insurance and a Moldovan family doctor can go to a private medical laboratory to request a test.  Private laboratories will require payment at the time of service. Prices range from 700 to 800 Moldovan lei (MDL) (approximately $40-50).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220131170044/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

"Pupils and staff with symptoms, including mild cold symptoms, must stay at home and get tested by the municipal health service (GGD) or do a self-test.   Staff at primary and secondary schools and pupils in secondary education must wear a face mask while moving around the building. Children in primary years 6, 7 and 8 are strongly advised to wear a face mask while moving around the building. Face masks may be taken off in the classroom. Children under 18 no longer have to self-quarantine if someone they live with or have been in close contact with has coronavirus. This also applies to secondary school pupils aged 18 and over, and to students under 18 in secondary vocational education (MBO) and higher education (HBO and universities).  Schools must take measures to prevent transmission of the virus, like one-way corridors, staggered breaks and limiting contacts between pupils in different classes. Children who are able to go to and from school on their own should do so.  All teaching staff at schools, pupils at secondary schools and pupils in primary years 6, 7 and 8 should do a self-test at home twice a week as a precaution, if necessary with the help of a parent or guardian. This also applies to staff and pupils who have been vaccinated or have received their booster vaccination. If the result of the self-test is positive, the pupil or staff member must get tested by the GGD. If the result of the self-test is negative, they can return to school. The basic rules also still apply."  https://archive.fo/BVoeW
No policy change  https://archive.fo/BVoeW

"  https://archive.fo/ASJef#selection-163.0-265.141

"Where to show a coronavirus entry pass  You must show a coronavirus entry pass to gain admission to:    Hospitality venues, such as bars and restaurants (indoors and outdoors). This also includes department store cafÃ©s, hotel restaurants and sports clubhouses, and any outdoor seating areas at these establishments. At sports clubhouses, only people aged 18 and over have to show a coronavirus entry pass.   An establishment that serves food and drink may also host an activity for which a coronavirus entry pass is not required. If that activity is held in a separate space, coronavirus entry passes do not need to be shown.   Amusement parks, zoos, casinos, play and gaming venues (such as indoor playgrounds), saunas, spas, tanning salons and recreational transportation.   Locations with a continuous flow of visitors in sectors where coronavirus entry passes are mandatory (hospitality, sports, art and culture, and events). This includes museums and historic buildings.  Events with a continuous flow of visitors and no assigned seating, such as funfairs.  Events with assigned seating, venues for parties, performances and screenings.   Business events, such as trade fairs and conferences.   Professionals sports matches and competitions, indoors and outdoors, for spectators aged 13 and over.   Indoor sports facilities such as gyms, sports halls and swimming pools, for people aged 18 and over wishing to use these facilities for lessons, training, recreational sport and competitions and matches. This also applies to people wishing to use any indoor facilities, such as changing rooms, at a venue for outdoor sports.   Cultural venues, such as theatres, concert halls and cinemas.   Artistic and cultural activities, such as music and painting lessons, and singing, dance and theatre rehearsals, for participants aged 18 and over. "  https://archive.fo/BVoeW

"A recommendation of a 1-metre distance from other people than those within your household or corresponding close relations. Exemption for children in kindergarten and primary school, as well as people who provide services for children and young people or vulnerable groups.  A recommendation of a maximum of 10 guests in addition to the people within your household. Children in kindergartens and primary school may receive visits from other children in their cohort/class/department."  https://archive.fo/5yD9u

"A requirement to operate in accordance with the infection control rules. For kindergartens, schools, and adult education this means, in practice, a requirement to operate at green level measures in line with the traffic light model.  The national recommendations regarding the level of measures in kindergartens, schools, and adult education are removed.  The recommendation of regular testing is removed.    Higher education  A requirement to operate in accordance with the infection control rules.  A recommendation to attempt to strive for teaching requiring that people are physically present. Arrangements must be made for students to be able to study as normal and to have the best student life possible within the current recommendations.  The recommendation to keep a 1-metre distance may be disregarded in connection with teaching.  The recommendation of regular testing is removed."  https://archive.fo/DQOxs#selection-1999.0-2016.0

"Employers are required to ensure that employees work from home if this is feasible and does not have a negative impact on services that are important and necessary for the business, including activities to protect children and vulnerable groups. A requirement to wear a face covering in some public-facing areas of working life.  A recommendation of good ventilation."    https://archive.fo/5yD9u

"Work  A recommendation of a 1-metre distance.  Employers are recommended to consider the extent to which employees may work from home, based on the workplace in question. Such an assessment must focus on factors including the probability of infection at the workplace and vulnerability to high concurrent sick leave.  The distance requirement must be met.  A recommendation to wear a face covering when it is not possible to keep a distance, unless physical barriers like partitions, etc. have been put in place.  The recommendation to work from home and wear a face covering does not apply to services where this prevents employees from performing necessary statutory tasks for vulnerable groups, as well as children and young people."    "The requirement that alcohol may only be served until 11 pm and that alcohol must be served at tables is removed.  The venue must ensure that all guests can keep a 1-metre distance from other people than those within their household or corresponding close relations.  Venues that serve food or alcohol must not organise activities that naturally entail a shorter distance between guests than 1 metre, e.g. dancing.  The requirement to register guests is removed."    https://archive.fo/DQOxs#selection-2055.0-2087.221

"Indoor public events:  Without designated seating: a maximum of 30 people.  With designated seating: up to 1 500 people, in cohorts of up to 200 people.  Outdoor public events:  Without designated seating: a maximum of 200 people.  With designated seating: up to 3 000 people, in cohorts of up to 500 people.  There is no restriction on the number of participants with the necessary number of adults present at outdoor events associated with organised cultural, sports, and leisure activities for children and young people under the age of 20.  The following applies to public events that gather more than 200 people indoors or more than 500 people outdoors:  50% capacity allowed.  A distance of at least 2 metres between each cohort at all times.  Each cohort must have access to separate toilet facilities, and separate areas with cloakrooms and food or alcohol service, if relevant."  https://archive.fo/5yD9u

"Events and gatherings  No attendance restrictions for private events.  Public events:  No attendance restrictions.  A requirement to operate in accordance with the infection control rules.  A requirement that organisers familiarise themselves with the relevant infection control standards and follow them.  The organiser must ensure that all of the people present at events are able to keep a distance of at least 1 metre from people who do not belong to the same household or are corresponding close relations. An exemption is granted from this requirement for people in designated seating. This makes it possible to fill every seat in a venue when everyone in the audience is in designated seating. The organiser must make arrangements for people to be able to keep a distance in the rest of the venue or in the area around the event. There is also an exemption from the requirement to ensure that everyone in certain groups can keep a 1-metre distance, including participants at cultural and sports events, participants on certain courses, and people who belong to the same cohort in kindergarten or primary school.  Organisers who plan events for audiences of over 200 people must prepare a written plan for compliance with the infection control measures at the venue for the event. The organiser should mention and explain non-compliance with the infection control measures mentioned in the relevant infection control standard."  https://archive.fo/DQOxs#selection-2095.0-2143.312

It has therefore concluded that the measure has little impact on developments in the COVID-19 situation or on hospital capacity in Norway, and does not consider travel quarantine to be necessary"    https://archive.fo/KSt03

"People with COVID-19 are responsible for notifying their close contacts when they receive a positive test result, but the municipality may provide assistance if necessary. "If you cannot keep a distance of at least 1 metre: wear a face covering in shops, common areas in shopping centres, venues that serve food or alcohol, on public transport, in indoor station areas, at indoor events, libraries, and museums."  https://archive.fo/5yD9u

"A requirement to wear a face covering when it is not possible to keep a distance of at least 1 metre in shops, shopping centres, venues that serve food or alcohol, public transport, taxis, and indoor station areas. The requirement also applies to employees unless physical barriers have been put in place.  There is no requirement to wear a face covering while sitting at a table at a venue that serves food or alcohol or at an event while in designated seating."  https://archive.fo/DQOxs#selection-1955.0-1961.155

27/1/22  Education  All students returned to full-time teaching.    Find out more about school rules.    Nurseries and kindergartens  Nurseries and kindergartens are open and provide care for children.    Illness, quarantine or isolation of the child  A person covered by sickness insurance is entitled to an allowance in the event of a need to care for a sick child, including when the child has been subject to isolation or quarantine. Care allowance may also be used by a parent who has to look after a healthy child up to the age of 8 due to the unexpected closure of the institution the child attends.    You can learn more about the care allowance on the ZUS website .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121112116/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/opieka-i-edukacja

27/1/22  Education  From Thursday, January 27 to February 27, 2022, students of grades 5-8 of primary schools and all grades of secondary schools take classes in a remote form.    Students in grades 1- 4 of primary schools continue their education in a full-time mode.    Detailed information is available on the website of the Ministry of Education and Science .    Find out more about general school rules.    Nurseries and kindergartens  Nurseries and kindergartens are open and provide care for children.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121112116/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/opieka-i-edukacja

Detailed information is available on the website of the Ministry of Education and Science .    Find out more about general school rules. 25/2/22  All students have returend to school.    From February 21, 2022, all students returned to full-time education.     Detailed information is available on the website of the Ministry of Education and Science .    Find out more about general school rules.    Face masks are still required    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225131746/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/opieka-i-edukacja    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.

6/2/22    Attention! The number of persons vaccinated against COVID-19 is not counted if they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Museums and art galleries  They function in a strict sanitary regime. There is a limit of people - 1 person. on 15 m2.    Cinemas  They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. It is necessary to cover the mouth and nose.    It is not allowed to eat or drink in the cinemas.    Theaters, operas, philharmonics  Outdoor:    They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. Maintain a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners.    In rooms:    They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. Maintain a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners. Ensuring that no more than 1 person per 15 m2 of the area is present in the room at the same time. It is necessary to cover the mouth and nose.    Houses and centers of culture  Conducting activities by cultural centers and centers as well as community centers is allowed in the open air and indoors, provided that the participation does not exceed 30%. participants. Ensure that participants follow the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Concerts and circus performances  Events may take place under the following conditions:    making available to viewers or listeners no more than 30 percent. number of seats,    keep a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners in the absence of designated seats in the audience and ensure that no more than 1 person per 15 square meters is present in the room at the same time,    ensure that viewers or listeners comply with the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Concerts and circus performances may be organized outdoors under the following conditions:    making available to viewers or listeners no more than 30 percent. number of seats,    keep a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners in the absence of designated seats in the audience,    ensure that viewers or listeners comply with the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Outdoor amusement parks  Amusement parks may operate at up to 30%. occupancy.    Libraries  Possibility to make collections available, provided that no more than 1 person per 15 mÂ² is present in the library, with the exception of librarians. Before entering the library, information about the limit of people should be posted.    Conducting activities by public and scientific libraries consisting in the organization of meetings and events is allowed indoors, provided that:    while maintaining a distance of 1.5 m between participants;    that participants comply with the obligation to cover their mouth and nose.    Night clubs, discos and other places available for dancing  Nightclubs, discos and other places to dance have closed.    Fairs, exhibitions, congresses, conferences  Trade fairs, congresses and conferences can be organized within the limit of 1 person per 15 m2.

6/2/22  Assembly  All types of meetings may be attended by up to 100 people. Participants are required to keep 1.5 m away from other people. In addition, the distance between assemblies must not be less than 100 m.    Meetings  Up to 100 people can participate in outdoor events and meetings, either in the premises or in a dedicated social area . There is a distance between the tables (every second table can be occupied, the distance between the tables must be at least 1.5 m - unless there is a partition at least 1 m high between them, counting from the surface of the table) .    Weddings, communions, consolations and other celebrations  You can organize special events outside and inside (e.g. in a restaurant). There is a limit of people - max. 100. Such events could take place in strict sanitary regime. There is a distance between the tables (every second table can be occupied, the distance between the tables must be at least 1.5 m - unless there is a partition at least 1 m high between them, counting from the surface of the table) .    go to end view    https://web.archive.org/web/20220204133826/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zgromadzenia-i-imprezy

6/2/22    Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians.  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    Important! Only persons with a medical certificate or a document confirming:    pervasive development disorders,  mental disorders,  moderate, severe or severe intellectual disability,  difficulty uncovering or covering your mouth or nose on your own.  advanced neurological, respiratory or circulatory disorders with respiratory or circulatory failure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128094644/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

31/1/22  For travellers arriving from the 6 soiuthern African countries; Republic of Botswana, the Kingdom of Eswatini, Lesotho, the Republic of Mozambique, the Republic of Namibia, South Africa or the Republic of Zimbabwe, you must qaurantine regardless of vaccination status and cannot shorten it by testing.    https://archive.vn/5nKAI

If your trip started from the territory of the Republic of Botswana, the Kingdom of Eswatini, Lesotho, the Republic of Mozambique, the Republic of Namibia, South Africa or the Republic of Zimbabwe , you cannot shorten the quarantine - you will be there for 14 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121113541/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/granice-i-ruch-miedzynarodowy

11/2/22    Attention! Rules for travelers coming to Poland from European Union Member States, from the Schengen area and others  If you are traveling with:    European Union Member States,  Switzerland  Iceland,  Norway  Liechtenstein,  Principality of Andorra,  Principalities of Monaco,  The Republic of San Marino,  Vatican City State  you are subject to a 7-day quarantine.     You are not quarantined if:    you are vaccinated with the full vaccination course:  a vaccine that is authorized in the European Union or is included in the list of vaccine equivalents authorized for marketing in the territory of the Republic of Poland, kept by the National Institute of Public Health PZH - National Research Institute,  14 days have elapsed since the administration of the last dose of vaccination (counted from the day following the administration of the last dose),  vaccination is certified by the EU digital COVID certificate or other document in Polish or English confirming the vaccination.  You have been infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus (you are the so-called healer):  not later than 6 months before the day of crossing the PR border,  you have a document that confirms the presence of the disease, issued in Polish or English, including the EU COVID Certificate,  You will present a negative COVID-19 test result:  certified by the EU digital COVID certificate or other document in Polish or English,  the test must be performed no earlier than 48 hours before crossing the border,  You are 12 or under and traveling with adults who are vaccinated against COVID-19 or tested negative for COVID-19.  You are subject to other exemptions listed in Â§ 3 of the Regulation of the Council of Ministers of May 6, 2021 on the establishment of certain restrictions, orders and bans in connection with the occurrence of an epidemic.  If you have been quarantined, you can perform a test up to 48 hours after crossing the border, the negative result of which will release you from quarantine.    Also check who is exempt from the obligation to quarantine after crossing the state border.    What test can I do?    Test type: RT-PCR and antigen test.  Tests are not publicly funded.  Are you a foreigner?    Check the border crossing rules for foreigners.    Traveler Location Card  A person who crosses the state border of the Republic of Poland by plane fills in the Traveler Location Card in an electronic form before check-in , and if this is not possible - a paper-based travel location card provided by the cabin crew.    The data administrator is the state poviat sanitary inspector competent for the place of residence or stay of the traveler.    EU COVID Certificate  The EU COVID Certificate is issued by the Ministry of Health. A vaccination certificate is issued:    in electronic form,  in paper form;  by providers of immunization against COVID-19,  by a primary care physician or primary care nurse.  Detailed information on the EU COVID Certificate .    Important! This communication is provided for information purposes only and cannot be used as a basis for adjudicating on a case-by-case basis. The verification on the basis of the document presented for inspection and the final decision on quarantine or grounds for exemption from such a requirement will be taken by a Border Guard officer who performs border control.    In disputed / doubtful / random matters regarding sanitary restrictions / quarantine / vaccinations - including the rules for exemptions, shortening its duration - the only competent authority is the State (Border) Sanitary Inspector at the local level, or a higher level authority, i.e. the Minister responsible for Health (Chief Sanitary Inspector).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221121222/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-ze-strefy-schengen

25/2/22  For those arriving from outside the Schengen area that are unvaccinated quarantine is required. For all vaccinated travellers a PCR test is required for entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214181845/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-spoza-strefy-schengen

No new policies. Continued policy is an increase to income for the âtax-free allowanceâ for low-wage earners. Also an increase to the threshold that triggers for individual taxpayers, application of the higher income tax bracket of 32% to PLN 120,000 (currently PLN 85,528), and an increase to the total tax and contribution burden for non-deductible health insurance contributions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211201130444/https://home.kpmg/us/en/home/insights/2021/05/tnf-poland-proposed-economic-stimulus-plan-tax-measures.html

6/2/22    Change in policy. Test are now available for anyone at a pharmacy without prior registration    How to get a coronavirus test at a pharmacy  No signups, no long waiting times and free of charge - now you can get tested at the pharmacy if you are concerned that you have the coronavirus. Check in which pharmacies near you can make it and on what terms!    In the pharmacy, you can do an antigen test:    without prior registration;  free;  unlimited - as many times as you need,  fast - the result after only a dozen or so minutes!  How to do it  Come to the pharmacy where the tests are performed - but be careful! Not every pharmacy participates in the program. Find out where the nearest pharmacy that runs the tests is .  The pharmacist will take a swab.  After a dozen or so minutes, you will receive the result and the pharmacist will enter it in the system.  You can also find information about the result on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .  Test results  If your score is:    negative - you will receive the EU COVID Certificate after the antigen test (valid for 48 hours),  positive - you will start home insulation .  Information on how long your isolation will last and certificates can be found on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .    Attention! Antigen tests are carried out in pharmacies. After a negative antigen test result, you can generate an EU COVID Certificate (UCC), but it will only be valid for 48 hours .    If you fall ill with the coronavirus and confirm the disease with the antigen test, you will not get the convalescent status and the EU COVID Certificate after 10 days!    Recover status confirmed by UCC can only be obtained after confirming the disease with  a PCR test performed at the collection point . Check how to sign up for a test at a download point .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206124352/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/jak-zrobic-test-na-koronawirusa-w-aptece

Information on how long your isolation will last and certificates can be found on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .    Attention! Antigen tests are carried out in pharmacies. After a negative antigen test result, you can generate an EU COVID Certificate (UCC), but it will only be valid for 48 hours .    If you fall ill with the coronavirus and confirm the disease with the antigen test, you will not get the convalescent status and the EU COVID Certificate after 10 days!    Recover status confirmed by UCC can only be obtained after confirming the disease with  a PCR test performed at the collection point . Check how to sign up for a test at a download point .      https://web.archive.org/web/20220204154012/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zapisz-sie-na-test-na-koronawirusa

No change  Limited contact tracing in place.    I was in close contact with a person who tested positive. Should I report it somewhere?  If you are in close contact with a person infected with the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus (this person has obtained a confirmed, positive PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infection), report this fact to the sanitary inspection. Use the online form: Application for quarantine or isolation by the Sanepid.    If you have questions about quarantine, please call the hotline to contact the sanitary inspection : +48 22 25 00 115. The  hotline is open 24 hours a day.    Important! If you know you have been in close contact with an infected or sick person, stay home - even if you have not yet decided to quarantine, and you are feeling well. Avoid contact with other people. You can infect them if you find out that you are infected. If this is not possible, use all required personal protective equipment.    Attention! If you have been vaccinated for COVID-19, you will not be placed in quarantine. The rule applies from December 28, 2020.    However, from December 15, family  members of people suffering from COVID19 must undergo a coronavirus test, regardless of the certificate they have.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

11/2/22    Social distance and face masks  Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians.  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  The nose and mouth may only be covered with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    Important! Only persons with a medical certificate or a document confirming:    pervasive development disorders,  mental disorders,  moderate, severe or severe intellectual disability,  difficulty uncovering or covering your mouth or nose on your own.  advanced neurological, respiratory or circulatory disorders with respiratory or circulatory failure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121112908/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

6/2/22    We want as many people as possible to receive the preparation against Covid-19 in the shortest possible time. It is in the interest of all of us - the vaccine offers a real chance of recovery.    E-referral    This is the document that entitles you to have the vaccine. In most cases, it is generated automatically for people who can sign up for a vaccination. Only in some cases do patients report to the doctor for this document. This happens when a given person does not have a PESEL number, or in the case of specific patients with the indicated diseases - they are informed about it.    The e-referral is valid for 90 days, but don't hesitate. If you have the opportunity, sign up for the vaccination now!    Registration for vaccination    Anyone who has an e-referral can sign up for a vaccination. There are several ways to do this:    call the helpline 989,  register online via e-Registration,  send an SMS saying SzczepimySie to the number 880 333 333,  sign up directly at the vaccination point (preferably by phone),  use the drive-thru point .     https://web.archive.org/web/20220127030346/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/jak-sie--zaszczepic

27/1/22  Booster dose  If you are over 50 years of age and 5 months have passed since you vaccinated, you can now have a booster dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. All other adults may receive a booster dose 6 months after the full dose of the vaccine. Vaccinations are the most effective weapon in the fight against severe disease and death.    https://archive.fo/eEqAV

Students in public and private university institutions must possess any of the  evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the building of the  institution.    4.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine  against COVID-19;  4.2 Persons with medical evidence from a specialist in the relevant field that they  have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination, must possess a  negative RT-PCR test for COVID 19 not older than one week;    The teaching process in public and private institutions of higher education, as well as  in vocational and non-formal education institutions, can take place with physical  presence provided that groups over 50 people are accommodated in no more than 50% of  the space.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

All employees of public institutions, central and local public enterprises, private  businesses, organizations, as well as other entities, must possess one of the following  evidence, in order to be allowed to enter the work premises:  4.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine  against COVID-19;  4.2 Persons with medical evidence from a specialist in the relevant field that they  have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination, must possess a  negative RT-PCR test for COVID 19 not older than one week;    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

Unless otherwise specified in this Decision, indoor gatherings of up to thirty (30) persons  (workshops, meetings, seminars, trainings or other gatherings) are allowed. Except those  under the age of 12, participants are obliged to possess any of the evidence mentioned in  points 25.1 to 25.3 in order to be allowed to enter these premises, and the organizer is  obliged to provide a physical distance of one (1) meter between persons and check the  relevant evidence, such as:  25.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen  vaccine against COVID-19;  25.2 Persons with medical evidence issued by the specialist doctor of the  respective field verifying that they have contraindications and are exempt  from vaccination must present the negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19,  which should not be older than 48 hours;  25.3 Single dose vaccination certificate, not older than one (1) month.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

Restriction of citizens' movement shall be from 00:00 to 05:00, except:  13.1 Cases of an emergency nature (to seek medical help, purchase medication,  provide care or medical assistance, avoid injury, or escape the risk of injury);  13.2 Circulation for health, safety personnel, and operators performing public  works and services;  13.3 Night shift personnel of economic operators who ensure the functioning of  the supply chain (including transport of goods/services), but provided that  they are provided with a special permit from the EDI system of the Tax  Administration of Kosovo;  13.4 Persons who provide proof that they must be at the airport during the  circulation restriction, because they have to travel by plane;  13.5 Persons to whom a special temporary permit is issued by the Emergency  Operational Centre of the Ministry of Internal Affairs, according to point 15,  due to the necessity of circulation during curfew.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

Every person who enters the Republic of Kosovo shall possess one of the following  evidence:  2.1 Certificate of full vaccination with two doses or a single-dose of Janssen  (J&J) vaccine not exceeding more than 12 months after receiving the last  dose;  2.2 Certificate of vaccination with a single dose accompanied with a negative  RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  2.3 Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90  days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days);  2.4 Evidence that the person has received the third / booster dose;  2.5 Evidence of negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours.    Citizens of the Republic of Kosovo who do not have two doses of vaccine are  obliged to respect home quarantine for a period of seven (7) days from the  entry into the territory of the Republic of Kosovo;     https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Kosovo? Yes  There are PCR and rapid antigen tests available from several private labs in Pristina and major towns in Kosovo.  The main public hospital in Pristina, the University Clinical Center of Kosovo (UCCK), provides free travel testing without a referral although availability and scheduling depend on demand.  Are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Turn-around time for results from the private clinics vary from several hours to 24 hours and are available via email and hard copy. Results from UCCK are reportedly available within 24 hours, but it is best to check with them due to expected higher demand.  If you are in Kosovo and have COVID-19 related questions, are symptomatic, or need information regarding testing, please call toll free 038 200 80 800, or dial 194.  The U.S. Embassy does not endorse or recommend any particular healthcare provider, but below is a list of clinics and hospitals who are providing tests. Please contact them directly for details on location, tests offered, and pricing:  Medical and Laboratory Services SHPK, +383 48 111 000 or +383 38 600 188  Prolab, +383 49 789 410  Olive Lab, +383 38 720 055, +383 49 520 056  UBT â Laboratory I Microbiology e Clinic, + 383 46 500 777, +383 46 500 888  Avicena, +383 49 825 555  UCCK â University Clinical Center Kosovo (public hospital), +381 38 500 600    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211185746/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

Are vaccines available in Kosovo for U.S. citizens to receive? Yes. The vaccine is available to both resident U.S. citizens and visitors without an appointment. For more details please see Kosovo Ministry of Health information available in Albanian and Serbian only.  Which vaccines are available in Kosovo? Astra Zeneca and Pfizer. The vaccine is limited to individuals over the age of 12.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211185746/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

A European Union Digital COVID Certificate or Romanian-issued âDigital Green Certificate/Green Passâ is necessary to access many public locations and to participate in certain activities such as: indoor or outdoor seated dining at restaurants, access to shopping malls, museums, exhibitions, cultural sites, non-essential stores, swimming pools, gyms and other venues. The Green Pass is not required for locations that provide essential services, such as food stores, pharmacies with direct access, or religious services.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220214183531/https://ro.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  It is a legal requirement to wear a medical-grade mask in all indoor and outdoor public spaces.   http://web.archive.org/web/20220214183735/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/romania/coronavirus

Bars and restaurants can stay open until 10 p.m. and operate at 50% or 30% capacity depending on the areaâs infection rate, and COVID-19 passes are required.The same goes for sporting events, gyms, and cinemas.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220214184204/https://www.euronews.com/2022/01/08/new-covid-19-measures-in-romania-as-infections-surge  A European Union Digital COVID Certificate or Romanian-issued âDigital Green Certificate/Green Passâ is necessary to access many public locations and to participate in certain activities such as: indoor or outdoor seated dining at restaurants, access to shopping malls, museums, exhibitions, cultural sites, non-essential stores, swimming pools, gyms and other venues. The Green Pass is not required for locations that provide essential services, such as food stores, pharmacies with direct access, or religious services.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220214183531/https://ro.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
